<p>âSo do I,â said Gandalf. âAnd I wonder many other things. Good-bye now! Take care of yourself! Look out for me, especially at unlikely times! Good-bye!â</p>
<p>Frodo saw him to the door. He gave a final wave of his hand, and walked off at a surprising pace; but Frodo thought the old wizard looked unusually bent, almost as if he was carrying a great weight. The evening was closing in, and his cloaked figure quickly vanished into the twilight. Frodo did not see him again for a long time.</p>
</section><section><title><p>Chapter 2</p>
<p>The Shadow of the Past</p>
</title><p>The talk did not die down in nine or even ninety-nine days. The second disappearance of Mr. Bilbo Baggins was discussed in Hobbiton, and indeed all over the Shire, for a year and a day, and was remembered much longer than that. It became a fireside-story for young hobbits; and eventually Mad Baggins, who used to vanish with a bang and a flash and reappear with bags of jewels and gold, became a favourite character of legend and lived on long after all the true events were forgotten.</p>
<p>But in the meantime, the general opinion in the neighbourhood was that Bilbo, who had always been rather cracked, had at last gone quite mad, and had run off into the Blue. There he had undoubtedly fallen into a pool or a river and come to a tragic, but hardly an untimely, end. The blame was mostly laid on Gandalf.</p>
<p>âIf only that dratted wizard will leave young Frodo alone, perhaps heâll settle down and grow some hobbit-sense,â they said. And to all appearance the wizard did leave Frodo alone, and he did settle down, but the growth of hobbit-sense was not very noticeable. Indeed, he at once began to carry on Bilboâs reputation for oddity. He refused to go into mourning; and the next year he gave a party in honour of Bilboâs hundred-and-twelfth birthday, which he called Hundred-weight Feast. But that was short of the mark, for twenty guests were invited and there were several meals at which it snowed food and rained drink, as hobbits say.</p>
<p>Some people were rather shocked; but Frodo kept up the custom of giving Bilboâs Birthday Party year after year until they got used to it. He said that he did not think Bilbo was dead. When they asked: âWhere is he then?â he shrugged his shoulders.</p>
<p>He lived alone, as Bilbo had done; but he had a good many friends, especially among the younger hobbits (mostly descendants of the Old Took) who had as children been fond of Bilbo and often in and out of Bag End. Folco Boffin and Fredegar Bolger were two of these; but his closest friends were Peregrin Took (usually called Pippin), and Merry Brandybuck (his real name was Meriadoc, but that was seldom remembered). Frodo went tramping all over the Shire with them; but more often he wandered by himself, and to the amazement of sensible folk he was sometimes seen far from home walking in the hills and woods under the starlight. Merry and Pippin suspected that he visited the Elves at times, as Bilbo had done.</p>
<p>As time went on, people began to notice that Frodo also showed signs of good âpreservationâ: outwardly he retained the appearance of a robust and energetic hobbit just out of his tweens. âSome folk have all the luck,â they said; but it was not until Frodo approached the usually more sober age of fifty that they began to think it queer.</p>
<p>Frodo himself, after the first shock, found that being his own master and <emphasis>the</emphasis> Mr. Baggins of Bag End was rather pleasant. For some years he was quite happy and did not worry much about the future. But half unknown to himself the regret that he had not gone with Bilbo was steadily growing. He found himself wondering at times, especially in the autumn, about the wild lands, and strange visions of mountains that he had never seen came into his dreams. He began to say to himself: âPerhaps I shall cross the River myself one day.â To which the other half of his mind always replied: âNot yet.â</p>
<p>So it went on, until his forties were running out, and his fiftieth birthday was drawing near: fifty was a number that he felt was somehow significant (or ominous); it was at any rate at that age that adventure had suddenly befallen Bilbo. Frodo began to feel restless, and the old paths seemed too well-trodden. He looked at maps, and wondered what lay beyond their edges: maps made in the Shire showed mostly white spaces beyond its borders. He took to wandering further afield and more often by himself; and Merry and his other friends watched him anxiously. Often he was seen walking and talking with the strange wayfarers that began at this time to appear in the Shire.</p>
<p>There were rumours of strange things happening in the world outside; and as Gandalf had not at that time appeared or sent any message for several years, Frodo gathered all the news he could. Elves, who seldom walked in the Shire, could now be seen passing westward through the woods in the evening, passing and not returning; but they were leaving Middle-earth and were no longer concerned with its troubles. There were, however, dwarves on the road in unusual numbers. The ancient East-West Road ran through the Shire to its end at the Grey Havens, and dwarves had always used it on their way to their mines in the Blue Mountains. They were the hobbitsâ chief source of news from distant parts â if they wanted any: as a rule dwarves said little and hobbits asked no more. But now Frodo often met strange dwarves of far countries, seeking refuge in the West. They were troubled, and some spoke in whispers of the Enemy and of the Land of Mordor.</p>
<p>That name the hobbits only knew in legends of the dark past, like a shadow in the background of their memories; but it was ominous and disquieting. It seemed that the evil power in Mirkwood had been driven out by the White Council only to reappear in greater strength in the old strongholds of Mordor. The Dark Tower had been rebuilt, it was said. From there the power was spreading far and wide, and away far east and south there were wars and growing fear. Orcs were multiplying again in the mountains. Trolls were abroad, no longer dull-witted, but cunning and armed with dreadful weapons. And there were murmured hints of creatures more terrible than all these, but they had no name.</p>
<p>Little of all this, of course, reached the ears of ordinary hobbits. But even the deafest and most stay-at-home began to hear queer tales; and those whose business took them to the borders saw strange things. The conversation in <emphasis>The Green Dragon</emphasis> at Bywater, one evening in the spring of Frodoâs fiftieth year, showed that even in the comfortable heart of the Shire rumours had been heard, though most hobbits still laughed at them.</p>
<p>Sam Gamgee was sitting in one corner near the fire, and opposite him was Ted Sandyman, the millerâs son; and there were various other rustic hobbits listening to their talk.</p>
<p>âQueer things you do hear these days, to be sure,â said Sam.</p>
<p>âAh,â said Ted, âyou do, if you listen. But I can hear fireside-tales and childrenâs stories at home, if I want to.â</p>
<p>âNo doubt you can,â retorted Sam, âand I daresay thereâs more truth in some of them than you reckon. Who invented the stories anyway? Take dragons now.â</p>
<p>âNo thank âee,â said Ted, âI wonât. I heard tell of them when I was a youngster, but thereâs no call to believe in them now. Thereâs only one Dragon in Bywater, and thatâs Green,â he said, getting a general laugh.</p>
<p>âAll right,â said Sam, laughing with the rest. âBut what about these Tree-men, these giants, as you might call them? They do say that one bigger than a tree was seen up away beyond the North Moors not long back.â</p>
<p>âWhoâs <emphasis>they</emphasis> ?â</p>
<p>âMy cousin Hal for one. He works for Mr. Boffin at Overhill and goes up to the Northfarthing for the hunting. He <emphasis>saw</emphasis> one.â</p>
<p>âSays he did, perhaps. Your Halâs always saying heâs seen things; and maybe he sees things that ainât there.â</p>
<p>âBut this one was as big as an elm tree, and walking â walking seven yards to a stride, if it was an inch.â</p>
<p>âThen I bet it wasnât an inch. What he saw <emphasis>was</emphasis> an elm tree, as like as not.â</p>
<p>âBut this one was <emphasis>walking</emphasis>, I tell you; and there ainât no elm tree on the North Moors.â</p>
<p>âThen Hal canât have seen one,â said Ted. There was some laughing and clapping: the audience seemed to think that Ted had scored a point.</p>
<p>âAll the same,â said Sam, âyou canât deny that others besides our Halfast have seen queer folk crossing the Shire â crossing it, mind you: there are more that are turned back at the borders. The Bounders have never been so busy before.</p>
<p>âAnd Iâve heard tell that Elves are moving west. <p>âThey are sailing, sailing, sailing over the Sea, they are going into the West and leaving us,â said Sam, half chanting the words, shaking his head sadly and solemnly. But Ted laughed.</p>
<p>âWell, that isnât anything new, if you believe the old tales. And I donât see what it matters to me or you. Let them sail! But I warrant you havenât seen them doing it; nor any one else in the Shire.â</p>
<p>âWell I donât know,â said Sam thoughtfully. He believed he had once seen an Elf in the woods, and still hoped to see more one day. <p>âOh, theyâre both cracked,â said Ted. âLeastways old Bilbo was cracked, and Frodoâs cracking. If thatâs where you get your news from, youâll never want for moonshine. Well, friends, Iâm off home. Your good health!â He drained his mug and went out noisily.</p>
<p>Sam sat silent and said no more. He had a good deal to think about. For one thing, there was a lot to do up in the Bag End garden, and he would have a busy day tomorrow, if the weather cleared. The grass was growing fast. But Sam had more on his mind than gardening. After a while he sighed, and got up and went out.</p>
<p>It was early April and the sky was now clearing after heavy rain. The sun was down, and a cool pale evening was quietly fading into night. He walked home under the early stars through Hobbiton and up the Hill, whistling softly and thoughtfully.</p>
<p>It was just at this time that Gandalf reappeared after his long absence. For three years after the Party he had been away. Then he paid Frodo a brief visit, and after taking a good look at him he went off again. During the next year or two he had turned up fairly often, coming unexpectedly after dusk, and going off without warning before sunrise. <p>Then suddenly his visits had ceased. It was over nine years since Frodo had seen or heard of him, and he had begun to think that the wizard would never return and had given up all interest in hobbits. But that evening, as Sam was walking home and twilight was fading, there came the once familiar tap on the study window.</p>
<p>Frodo welcomed his old friend with surprise and great delight. They looked hard at one another.</p>
<p>âAh well eh?â said Gandalf. âYou look the same as ever, Frodo!â</p>
<p>âSo do you,â Frodo replied; but secretly he thought that Gandalf looked older and more careworn. He pressed him for news of himself and of the wide world, and soon they were deep in talk, and they stayed up far into the night.</p>
<p>Next morning after a late breakfast, the wizard was sitting with Frodo by the open window of the study. A bright fire was on the hearth, but the sun was warm, and the wind was in the South. <p>Gandalf was thinking of a spring, nearly eighty years before, when Bilbo had run out of Bag End without a handkerchief. <empty-line/><image l:href="#gandalf_frodo.jpg"/><p>He was smoking now in silence, for Frodo was sitting still, deep in thought. Even in the light of morning he felt the dark shadow of the tidings that Gandalf had brought. At last he broke the silence.</p>
<p>âLast night you began to tell me strange things about my ring, Gandalf,â he said. âAnd then you stopped, because you said that such matters were best left until daylight. <p>âIn many ways,â answered the wizard. It is far more powerful than I ever dared to think at first, so powerful that in the end it would utterly overcome anyone of mortal race who possessed it. It would possess him.</p>
<p>âIn Eregion long ago many Elven-rings were made, magic rings as you call them, and they were, of course, of various kinds: some more potent and some less. <p>âA mortal, Frodo, who keeps one of the Great Rings, does not die, but he does not grow or obtain more life, he merely continues, until at last every minute is a weariness. And if he often uses the Ring to make himself invisible, he <emphasis>fades:</emphasis> he becomes in the end invisible permanently, and walks in the twilight under the eye of the dark power that rules the Rings. <p>âHow terrifying!â said Frodo. There was another long silence. The sound of Sam Gamgee cutting the lawn came in from the garden.</p>
<p>âHow long have you known this?â asked Frodo at length. âAnd how much did Bilbo know?â</p>
<p>âBilbo knew no more than he told you, I am sure,â said Gandalf. âHe would certainly never have passed on to you anything that he thought would be a danger, even though I promised to look after you. <p>âYes, he warned me of that in his last letter,â said Frodo, âso I have always kept it on its chain.â</p>
<p>âVery wise,â said Gandalf. âBut as for his long life, Bilbo never connected it with the ring at all. He took all the credit for that to himself, and he was very proud of it. <p>âHow long have you known all this?â asked Frodo again.</p>

<p>âWhen did I first begin to guess?â he mused, searching back in memory. âLet me see â it was in the year that the White Council drove the dark power from Mirkwood, just before the Battle of Five Armies, that Bilbo found his ring. <p>âWho is he?â asked Frodo. I have never heard of him before.â</p>
<p>âMaybe not,â answered Gandalf. âHobbits are, or were, no concern of his. Yet he is great among the Wise. He is the chief of my order and the head of the Council. <p>âAnd all seemed well with Bilbo. And the years passed. Yes, they passed, and they seemed not to touch him. He showed no signs of age. The shadow fell on me again. But I said to myself: âAfter all he comes of a long-lived family on his motherâs side. There is time yet. Wait!â</p>
<p>âAnd I waited. Until that night when he left this house. He said and did things then that filled me with a fear that no words of Saruman could allay. I knew at last that something dark and deadly was at work. And I have spent most of the years since then in finding out the truth of it.â</p>

<p>âHe felt better at once,â said Gandalf. âBut there is only one Power in this world that knows all about the Rings and their effects; and as far as I know there is no Power in the world that knows all about hobbits. <p>âOf course, he possessed the ring for many years, and used it, so it might take a long while for the influence to wear off â before it was safe for him to see it again, for instance. <p>âEver since Bilbo left I have been deeply concerned about you, and about all these charming, absurd, helpless hobbits. <p>Frodo took it from his breeches-pocket, where it was clasped to a chain that hung from his belt. He unfastened it and handed it slowly to the wizard. It felt suddenly very heavy, as if either it or Frodo himself was in some way reluctant for Gandalf to touch it.</p>

<p>As Frodo did so, he now saw fine lines, finer than the finest pen-strokes, running along the ring, outside and inside: lines of fire that seemed to form the letters of a flowing script. They shone piercingly bright, and yet remote, as if out of a great depth.</p>
<image l:href="#ring.jpg"/><p>âI cannot read the fiery letters,â said Frodo in a quavering voice.</p>

<poem><stanza><v>One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them,</v><v>One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.</v></stanza></poem><p>It is only two lines of a verse long known in Elven-lore:</p>
<poem><stanza><v>Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky,</v><v>Seven for the Dwarf-lords in their halls of stone,</v><v>Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die,</v><v>One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne</v><v>In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.</v><v>One Ring to rule them all. <p>Frodo sat silent and motionless. Fear seemed to stretch out a vast hand, like a dark cloud rising in the East and looming up to engulf him. âThis ring!â he stammered. âHow, how on earth did it come to me?â</p>
<p>âAh!â said Gandalf. âThat is a very long story. The beginnings lie back in the Black Years, which only the lore-masters now remember. If I were to tell you all that tale, we should still be sitting here when Spring had passed into Winter.</p>
<p>âBut last night I told you of Sauron the Great, the Dark Lord. The rumours that you have heard are true: he has indeed arisen again and left his hold in Mirkwood and returned to his ancient fastness in the Dark Tower of Mordor. <p>âI wish it need not have happened in my time,â said Frodo.</p>
<p>âSo do I,â said Gandalf, âand so do all who live to see such times. But that is not for them to decide. All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us. <p>âThe Enemy still lacks one thing to give him strength and knowledge to beat down all resistance, break the last defences, and cover all the lands in a second darkness. He lacks the One Ring.</p>
<p>âThe Three, fairest of all, the Elf-lords hid from him, and his hand never touched them or sullied them. <p>âSo it is now: the Nine he has gathered to himself; the Seven also, or else they are destroyed. The Three are hidden still. But that no longer troubles him. <p>âAnd this is the dreadful chance, Frodo. He believed that the One had perished; that the Elves had destroyed it, as should have been done. </section><section><title><p>Chapter 3</p>
<p>Three is Company</p>
</title><p>âYou ought to go quietly, and you ought to go soon,â said Gandalf. Two or three weeks had passed, and still Frodo made no sign of getting ready to go.</p>
<p>âI know. But it is difficult to do both,â he objected. If I just vanish like Bilbo, the tale will be all over the Shire in no time.â</p>
<p>âOf course you mustnât vanish!â said Gandalf. âThat wouldnât do at all! I said <emphasis>soon</emphasis>, not <emphasis>instantly</emphasis>. <p>To tell the truth, he was very reluctant to start, now that it had come to the point. <p>He looked at Frodo and smiled. âVery well,â he said. âI think that will do â but it must not be any later. I am getting very anxious. <p>âI have been so taken up with the thoughts of leaving Bag End, and of saying farewell, that I have never even considered the direction,â said Frodo. âFor where am I to go? <p>âBut you cannot see very far,â said Gandalf. âNeither can I. It may be your task to find the Cracks of Doom; but that quest may be for others: I do not know. At any rate you are not ready for that long road yet.â</p>

<p>âRivendell!â said Frodo. âVery good: I will go east, and I will make for Rivendell. <p>One summerâs evening an astonishing piece of news reached the <emphasis>Ivy Bush</emphasis> and <emphasis>Green Dragon</emphasis>. <p>âFor a nice bit, loo,â said some. âAt a bargain price,â said others, âand thatâs more likely when Mistress Lobeliaâs the buyer.â (Otho had died some years before, at the ripe but disappointed age of 102.)</p>
<p>Just why Mr. Frodo was selling his beautiful hole was even more debatable than the price. <p>Gandalf stayed in the Shire for over two months. <p>âWell no; but I have heard something that has made me anxious and needs looking into. <p>At first Frodo was a good deal disturbed, and wondered often what Gandalf could have heard; but his uneasiness wore off, and in the fine weather he forgot his troubles for a while. <p>Autumn was well under way before Frodo began to worry about Gandalf again. September was passing and there was still no news of him. <p>On September 20th two covered carts went off laden to Buckland, conveying the furniture and goods that Frodo had not sold to his new home, by way of the Brandywine Bridge. <p>The four younger hobbits were, however, in high spirits, and the party soon became very cheerful in spite of Gandalfâs absence. <p>âWhatever happens to the rest of my stuff, when the S.-B.s get their claws on it, at any rate I have found a good home for this!â said Frodo, as he drained his glass. It was the last drop of Old Winyards.</p>

<p>The next morning they were busy packing another cart with the remainder of the luggage. <p>âI shall get myself a bit into training, too,â he said, looking at himself in a dusty mirror in the half-empty hall. He had not done any strenuous walking for a long time, and the reflection looked rather flabby, he thought.</p>

<p>He took his own tea with Pippin and Sam Gamgee in the kitchen. <p>The sun went down. Bag End seemed sad and gloomy and dishevelled. Frodo wandered round the familiar rooms, and saw the light of the sunset fade on the walls, and shadows creep out of the corners. <p>The sky was clear and the stars were growing bright. âItâs going to be a fine night,â he said aloud. âThatâs good for a beginning. I feel like walking. <p>âWell, now weâre off at last!â said Frodo. <p>At the bottom of the Hill on its western side they came to the gate opening on to a narrow lane. There they halted and adjusted the straps of their packs. <p>âI am sure you have given me all the heaviest stuff,â said Frodo. âI pity snails, and all that carry their homes on their backs.â</p>

<p>For a short way they followed the lane westwards. Then leaving it they turned left and took quietly to the fields again. <p>After some time they crossed the Water, west of Hobbiton, by a narrow plank-bridge. The stream was there no more than a winding black ribbon, bordered with leaning alder-trees. <p>âI wonder if I shall ever look down into that valley again,â he said quietly.</p>
<p>When they had walked for about three hours they rested. The night was clear, cool, and starry, but smoke-like wisps of mist were creeping up the hill-sides from the streams and deep meadows. <p>After a while they plunged into a deeply cloven track between tall trees that rustled their dry leaves in the night. It was very dark. <p>âThe windâs in the West,â said Sam. âIf we get to the other side of this hill, we shall find a spot that is sheltered and snug enough, sir. <p>Just over the top of the hill they came on the patch of fir-wood. Leaving the road they went into the deep resin-scented darkness of the trees, and gathered dead sticks and cones to make a fire. <p>âHobbits!â he thought. âWell, what next? I have heard of strange doings in this land, but I have seldom heard of a hobbit sleeping out of doors under a tree. Three of them! Thereâs something mighty queer behind this.â He was quite right, but he never found out any more about it.</p>
<p>The morning came, pale and clammy. Frodo woke up first, and found that a tree-root had made a hole in his back, and that his neck was stiff.</p>
<p>âWalking for pleasure! Why didnât I drive?â he thought, as he usually did at the beginning of an expedition. âAnd all my beautiful feather beds are sold to the Sackville-Bagginses! <p>âWhatâs beautiful about it?â said Pippin, peering over the edge of his blanket with one eye. âSam! Gel breakfast ready for half-past nine! Have you got the bath-water hot?â</p>
<p>Sam jumped up, looking rather bleary. âNo, sir, I havenât, sir!â he said.</p>
<p>Frodo stripped the blankets from Pippin and rolled him over, and then walked off to the edge of the wood. Away eastward the sun was rising red out of the mists that lay thick on the world. <p>When he returned Sam and Pippin had got a good fire going. âWater!â shouted Pippin. âWhereâs the water?â</p>

<p>âYou can come too,â said Frodo, âand bring all the water-bottles.â There was a stream at the foot of the hill. <p>When their breakfast was over, and their packs all trussed up again, it was after ten oâclock, and the day was beginning to turn fine and hot. <p>The dayâs march promised to be warm and tiring work. <p>âThe road goes on for ever,â said Pippin; âbut I canât without a rest. <p>âDo Elves live in those woods?â he asked.</p>
<p>âNot that I ever heard,â said Pippin. Frodo was silent. He too was gazing eastward along the road, as if he had never seen it before. Suddenly he spoke, aloud but as if to himself, saying slowly:</p>
<poem><stanza><v>The Road goes ever on and on</v><v>Down from the door where it began.</v><v>Now far ahead the Road has gone,</v><v>And I must follow, if I can,</v><v>Pursuing it with weary feet,</v><v>Until it joins some larger way,</v><v>Where many paths and errands meet.</v><v>And whither then? <p>âWell, the Road wonât sweep me anywhere for an hour at least,â said Pippin, unslinging his pack. The others followed his example, putting their packs against the bank and their legs out into the road. After a rest they had a good lunch, and then more rest.</p>
<p>The sun was beginning to get low and the light of afternoon was on the land as they went down the hill. So far they had not met a soul on the road. <p>âI can hear a pony or a horse coming along the road behind,â said Sam.</p>
<p>They looked back, but the turn of the road prevented them from seeing far. âI wonder if that is Gandalf coming after us,â said Frodo; but even as he said it, he had a feeling that it was not so, and a sudden desire to hide from the view of the rider came over him.</p>
<p>âIt may not matter much,â he said apologetically, âbut I would rather not be seen on the road â by anyone. I am sick of my doings being noticed and discussed. <p>The other two ran quickly to the left and down into a little hollow not far from the road. There they lay flat. <p>Round the corner came a black horse, no hobbit-pony but a full-sized horse; and on it sat a large man, who seemed to crouch in the saddle, wrapped in a great black cloak and hood, so that only his boots in the high stirrups showed below; his face was shadowed and invisible.</p>
<p>When it reached the tree and was level with Frodo the horse stopped. The riding figure sat quite still with its head bowed, as if listening. From inside the hood came a noise as of someone sniffing to catch an elusive scent; the head turned from side to side of the road.</p>
<p>A sudden unreasoning fear of discovery laid hold of Frodo, and he thought of his Ring. <p>Frodo crawled to the edge of the road and watched the rider, until he dwindled into the distance. He could not be quite sure, but it seemed to him that suddenly, before it passed out of sight, the horse turned aside and went into the trees on the right.</p>

<p>âI have only just remembered, sir. <p>âAll right, cousin Frodo! You can keep your secret for the present, if you want to be mysterious. In the meanwhile what are we to do? I should like a bite and a sup, but somehow I think we had better move on from here. Your talk of sniffing riders with invisible noses has unsettled me.â</p>
<p>âYes, I think we will move on now,â said Frodo; âbut not on the road -in case that rider comes back, or another follows him. We ought to do a good step more today. Buckland is still miles away.â</p>
<p>The shadows of the trees were long and thin on the grass, as they started off again. They now kept a stoneâs throw to the left of the road, and kept out of sight of it as much as they could. <p>The sun had gone down red behind the hills at their backs, and evening was coming on before they came back to the road at the end of the long level over which it had run straight for some miles. <p>Not far from the road-meeting they came on the huge hulk of a tree: it was still alive and had leaves on the small branches that it had put out round the broken stumps of its long-fallen limbs; but it was hollow, and could be entered by a great crack on the side away from the road. <p>Twilight was about them as they crept back to the lane. The West wind was sighing in the branches. Leaves were whispering. Soon the road began to fall gently but steadily into the dusk. <poem><stanza><v>Upon the hearth the fire is red,</v><v>Beneath the roof there is a bed;</v><v>But not yet weary are our feet,</v><v>Still round the corner we may meet</v><v>A sudden tree or standing stone</v><v>That none have seen but we alone.</v></stanza><stanza><v>Tree and flower and leaf and grass,</v><v>Let them pass! <p>They slopped suddenly and stood as silent as tree-shadows, listening. There was a sound of hoofs in the lane, some way behind, but coming slow and clear down the wind. Quickly and quietly they slipped off the path, and ran into the deeper shade under the oak-trees.</p>
<p>âDonât let us go too far!â said Frodo. âI donât want to be seen, but I want to see if it is another Black Rider.â</p>

<p>The hoofs drew nearer. <p>The sound of hoofs stopped. As Frodo watched he saw something dark pass across the lighter space between two trees, and then halt. <p>Once more the desire to slip on the Ring came over Frodo; but this time it was stronger than before. <p>âYes, it is Elves,â said Frodo. âOne can meet them sometimes in the Woody End. <p>âWhat about the Elves?â said Sam, too excited to trouble about the rider. âCanât we go and see them?â</p>
<p>âListen! They are coming this way,â said Frodo. âWe have only to wait.â The singing drew nearer. One clear voice rose now above the others. <poem><stanza><v>Snow-white! Snow-white! <p>âO Fair Folk! This is good fortune beyond my hope,â said Pippin. Sam was speechless. âI thank you indeed, Gildor Inglorion,â said Frodo bowing. <emphasis>âElen sila lumennâ omentielvo</emphasis>, a star shines on the hour of our meeting,â he added in the high-elven speech.</p>
<p>âBe careful, friends!â cried Gildor laughing. âSpeak no secrets! Here is a scholar in the Ancient Tongue. Bilbo was a good master. <p>âWhy? Where are you going?â asked Frodo.</p>
<p>âFor tonight we go to the woods on the hills above Woodhall. It is some miles, but you shall have rest at the end of it, and it will shorten your journey tomorrow.â</p>
<p>They now marched on again in silence, and passed like shadows and faint lights: for Elves (even more than hobbits) could walk when they wished without sound of footfall. <p>The woods on either side became denser; the trees were now younger and thicker; and as the lane went lower, running down into a fold of the hills, there were many deep brakes of hazel on the rising slopes at either hand. <p>The Elves sat on the grass and spoke together in soft voices; they seemed to take no further notice of the hobbits. <p>Away high in the East swung Remmirath, the Netted Stars, and slowly above the mists red Borgil rose, glowing like a jewel of fire. Then by some shift of airs all the mist was drawn away like a veil, and there leaned up, as he climbed over the rim of the world, the Swordsman of the Sky, Menelvagor with his shining belt. <p>âCome!â the Elves called to the hobbits. âCome! Now is the time for speech and merriment!â</p>
<p>Pippin sat up and rubbed his eyes. He shivered. âThere is a fire in the hall, and food for hungry guests,â said an Elf standing before him.</p>
<p>At the south end of the greensward there was an opening. There the green floor ran on into the wood, and formed a wide space like a hall, roofed by the boughs of trees. Their great trunks ran like pillars down each side. In the middle there was a wood-fire blazing, and upon the tree-pillars torches with lights of gold and silver were burning steadily. The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks. Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drink; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes.</p>
<image l:href="#elves_woodyend.jpg"/><empty-line/><p>âThis is poor fare,â they said to the hobbits; âfor we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls. If ever you are our guests at home, we will treat you better.â</p>
<p>âIt seems to me good enough for a birthday-party,â said Frodo.</p>
<p>Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink, for his mind was filled with the light upon the elf-faces, and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that he felt in a waking dream. But he remembered that there was bread, surpassing the savour of a fair white loaf to one who is starving; and fruits sweet as wildberries and richer than the tended fruits of gardens; he drained a cup that was filled with a fragrant draught, cool as a clear fountain, golden as a summer afternoon.</p>
<p>Sam could never describe in words, nor picture clearly to himself, what he felt or thought that night, though it remained in his memory as one of the chief events of his life. <p>Frodo sat, eating, drinking, and talking with delight; but his mind was chiefly on the words spoken. He knew a little of the elf-speech and listened eagerly. Now and again he spoke to those that served him and thanked them in their own language. They smiled at him and said laughing: âHere is a jewel among hobbits!â</p>
<p>After a while Pippin fell fast asleep, and was lifted up and borne away to a bower under the trees; there he was laid upon a soft bed and slept the rest of the night away. Sam refused to leave his master. When Pippin had gone, he came and sat curled up at Frodoâs feet, where at last he nodded and closed his eyes. Frodo remained long awake, talking with Gildor.</p>
<p>They spoke of many things, old and new, and Frodo questioned Gildor much about happenings in the wide world outside the Shire. The tidings were mostly sad and ominous: of gathering darkness, the wars of Men, and the flight of the Elves. At last Frodo asked the question that was nearest to his heart:</p>
<p>âTell me, Gildor, have you ever seen Bilbo since he left us?â</p>
<p>Gildor smiled. âYes,â he answered. âTwice. He said farewell to us on this very spot. But I saw him once again, far from here.â He would say no more about Bilbo, and Frodo fell silent.</p>
<p>âYou do not ask me or tell me much that concerns yourself, Frodo,â said Gildor. âBut I already know a little, and I can read more in your face and in the thought behind your questions. <p>âIt is,â said Frodo; âbut I thought my going was a secret known only to Gandalf and my faithful Sam.â He looked down at Sam, who was snoring gently.</p>
<p>âThe secret will not reach the Enemy from us,â said Gildor.</p>

<p>âI do not know for what reason the Enemy is pursuing you,â answered Gildor; âbut I perceive that he is â strange indeed though that seems to me. And I warn you that peril is now both before you and behind you, and upon either side.â</p>

<p>âThen I think it is not for me to say more â lest terror should keep you from your journey. For it seems to me that you have set out only just in time, if indeed you are in time. You must now make haste, and neither stay nor turn back; for the Shire is no longer any protection to you.â</p>
<p>âI cannot imagine what information could be more terrifying than your hints and warnings,â exclaimed Frodo. âI knew that danger lay ahead, of course; but I did not expect to meet it in our own Shire. Canât a hobbit walk from the Water to the River in peace?â</p>
<p>âBut it is not your own Shire,â said Gildor. âOthers dwelt here before hobbits were; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more. The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.â</p>
<p>âI know â and yet it has always seemed so safe and familiar. What can I do now? My plan was to leave the Shire secretly, and make my way to Rivendell; but now my footsteps are dogged, before ever I get to Buckland.â</p>
<p>âI think you should still follow that plan,â said Gildor. âI do not think the Road will prove too hard for your courage. But if you desire clearer counsel, you should ask Gandalf. <p>âI hope so. But that is another thing that makes me anxious. I have been expecting Gandalf for many days. He was to have come to Hobbiton at the latest two nights ago; but he has never appeared. Now I am wondering what can have happened. Should I wait for him?â</p>
<p>Gildor was silent for a moment. âI do not like this news,â he said at last. âThat Gandalf should be late, does not bode well. But it is said: <emphasis>Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards, for they are subtle and quick to anger</emphasis>. The choice is yours: to go or wait.â</p>

<p>âIs it indeed?â laughed Gildor. âElves seldom give unguarded advice, for advice is a dangerous gift, even from the wise to the wise, and all courses may run ill. But what would you? The Elves have their own labours and their own sorrows, and they are little concerned with the ways of hobbits, or of any other creatures upon earth. <p>âI am deeply grateful,â said Frodo; âbut I wish you would tell me plainly what the Black Riders are. If I take your advice I may not see Gandalf for a long while, and I ought to know what is the danger that pursues me.â</p>
<p>âIs it not enough to know that they are servants of the Enemy?â answered Gildor. âFlee them! Speak no words to them! They are deadly. Ask no more of me! <p>âBut where shall I find courage?â asked Frodo. âThat is what I chiefly need.â</p>
<p>âCourage is found in unlikely places,â said Gildor. âBe of good hope! Sleep now! In the morning we shall have gone; but we will send our messages through the lands. <p>Frodo felt sleep coming upon him, even as Gildor finished speaking. âI will sleep now,â he said; and the Elf led him to a bower beside Pippin, and he threw himself upon a bed and fell at once into a dreamless slumber.</p>
</section><section><title><p>Chapter 4</p>
<p>A Short Cut to Mushrooms</p>
</title><p>In the morning Frodo woke refreshed. He was lying in a bower made by a living tree with branches laced and drooping to the ground; his bed was of fern and grass, deep and soft and strangely fragrant. The sun was shining through the fluttering leaves, which were still green upon the tree. He jumped up and went out.</p>
<p>Sam was sitting on the grass near the edge of the wood. Pippin was standing studying the sky and weather. There was no sign of the Elves.</p>
<p>âThey have left us fruit and drink, and bread,â said Pippin. âCome and have your breakfast. The bread tastes almost as good as it did last night. I did not want to leave you any, but Sam insisted.â</p>
<p>Frodo sat down beside Sam and began to eat. âWhat is the plan for today?â asked Pippin.</p>
<p>âTo walk to Bucklebury as quickly as possible,â answered Frodo, and gave his attention to the food.</p>
<p>âDo you think we shall see anything of those Riders?â asked Pippin cheerfully. Under the morning sun the prospect of seeing a whole troop of them did not seem very alarming to him.</p>
<p>âYes, probably,â said Frodo, not liking the reminder. âBut I hope to get across the river without their seeing us.â</p>
<p>âDid you find out anything about them from Gildor?â</p>
<p>âNot much â only hints and riddles,â said Frodo evasively.</p>
<p>âDid you ask about the sniffing?â</p>

<p>âYou should have. I am sure it is very important.â</p>
<p>âIn that case I am sure Gildor would have refused to explain it,â said Frodo sharply. âAnd now leave me in peace for a bit! I donât want to answer a string of questions while I am eating. I want to think!â</p>
<p>âGood heavens!â said Pippin. âAt breakfast?â He walked away towards the edge of the green.</p>
<p>From Frodoâs mind the bright morning â treacherously bright, he thought â had not banished the fear of pursuit; and he pondered the words of Gildor. The merry voice of Pippin came to him. He was running on the green turf and singing.</p>
<p>âNo! I could not!â he said to himself. âIt is one thing to take my young friends walking over the Shire with me, until we are hungry and weary, and food and bed are sweet. <p>âWell, Sam!â he said. âWhat about it? I am leaving the Shire as soon as ever I can â in fact I have made up my mind now not even to wait a day at Crickhollow, if it can be helped.â</p>
<p>âVery good, sir!â</p>
<p>âYou still mean to come with me?â</p>
<p>âI do.â</p>
<p>âIt is going to be very dangerous, Sam. âIt is already dangerous. Most likely neither of us will come back.â</p>
<p>âIf you donât come back, sir, then I shanât, thatâs certain,â said Sam. <emphasis>âDonât you leave him!</emphasis> they said to me. <emphasis>Leave him!</emphasis> I said. <emphasis>I never mean to. <p>âWho are <emphasis>they</emphasis>, and what are you talking about?â</p>
<p>âThe Elves, sir. We had some talk last night; and they seemed to know you were going away, so I didnât see the use of denying it. Wonderful folk, Elves, sir! Wonderful!â</p>
<p>âThey are,â said Frodo. âDo you like them still, now you have had a closer view?â</p>
<p>âThey seem a bit above my likes and dislikes, so to speak,â answered Sam slowly. âIt donât seem to matter what I think about them. They are quite different from what I expected â so old and young, and so gay and sad, as it were.â</p>
<p>Frodo looked at Sam rather startled, half expecting to see some outward sign of the odd change that seemed to have come over him. <p>âDo you feel any need to leave the Shire now â now that your wish to see them has come true already?â he asked.</p>
<p>âYes, sir. I donât know how to say it, but after last night I feel different. I seem to see ahead, in a kind of way. <p>âI donât altogether. But I understand that Gandalf chose me a good companion. I am content. We will go together.â</p>
<p>Frodo finished his breakfast in silence. Then standing up he looked over the land ahead, and called to Pippin.</p>
<p>âAll ready to start?â he said as Pippin ran up. âWe must be getting off at once. We slept late; and there are a good many miles to go.â</p>

<p>âWe can cut straighter than the road anyway,â answered Frodo. âThe Ferry is east from Woodhall; but the hard road curves away to the left â you can see a bend of it away north over there. <p><emphasis>âShort cuts make long delays,â</emphasis> argued Pippin. âThe country is rough round here, and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the Marish â I know the land in these parts. <p>âIt is less easy to find people in the woods and fields,â answered Frodo. âAnd if you are supposed to be on the road, there is some chance that you will be looked for on the road and not off it.â</p>
<p>âAll right!â said Pippin. âI will follow you into every bog and ditch. But it is hard! I had counted on passing the <emphasis>Golden Perch</emphasis> at Stock before sundown. The best beer in the Eastfarthing, or used to be: it is a long time since I tasted it.â</p>
<p>âThat settles it!â said Frodo. âShort cuts make delays, but inns make longer ones. At all costs we must keep you away from the <emphasis>Golden Perch.</emphasis> We want to get to Bucklebury before dark. What do you say, Sam?â</p>
<p>âI will go along with you, Mr. Frodo,â said Sam (in spite of private misgiving and a deep regret for the best beer in the Eastfarthing).</p>
<p>âThen if we are going to toil through bog and briar, letâs go now!â said Pippin.</p>
<p>It was already nearly as hot as it had been the day before; but clouds were beginning to come up from the West. It looked likely to turn to rain. The hobbits scrambled down a steep green bank and plunged into the thick trees below. Their course had been chosen to leave Woodhall to their left, and to cut slanting through the woods that clustered along the eastern side of the hills, until they reached the flats beyond. <p>He soon found that the thicket was closer and more tangled than it had appeared. There were no paths in the undergrowth, and they did not get on very fast. <p>Sam Gamgee looked back. Through an opening in the trees he caught a glimpse of the top of the green bank from which they had climbed down.</p>
<p>âLook!â he said, clutching Frodo by the arm. They all looked, and on the edge high above them they saw against the sky a horse standing. Beside it stooped a black figure.</p>
<p>They at once gave up any idea of going back. Frodo led the way, and plunged quickly into the thick bushes beside the stream. âWhew!â he said to Pippin. âWe were both right! <p>They stood still, almost holding their breath as they listened; but there was no sound of pursuit. âI donât fancy he would try bringing his horse down that bank,â said Sam. âBut I guess he knows we came down it. We had better be going on.â</p>
<p>Going on was not altogether easy. They had packs to carry, and the bushes and brambles were reluctant to let them through. <p>âWhy, this is the Stock-brook!â said Pippin. âIf we are going to try and get back on to our course, we must cross at once and bear right.â</p>
<p>They waded the stream, and hurried over a wide open space, rush-grown and treeless, on the further side. <p>After half an hour Pippin said: âI hope we have not turned too much towards the south, and are not walking longwise through this wood! It is not a very broad belt âI should have said no more than a mile at the widest â and we ought to have been through it by now.â</p>
<p>âIt is no good our starting to go in zig-zags,â said Frodo. âThat wonât mend matters. Let us keep on as we are going! I am not sure that I want to come out into the open yet.â</p>
<p>They went on for perhaps another couple of miles. Then the sun gleamed out of ragged clouds again and the rain lessened. It was now past mid-day, and they felt it was high time for lunch. <p>Frodo propped his back against the tree-trunk, and closed his eyes. Sam and Pippin sat near, and they began to hum, and then to sing softly:</p>
<poem><stanza><v>Ho! Ho! Ho! to the bottle I go</v><v>To heal my heart and drown my woe.</v><v>Rain may fall and wind may blow,</v><v>And many miles be still to go,</v><v>But under a tall tree I will lie,</v><v>And let the clouds go sailing by.</v></stanza></poem><p><emphasis>Ho! <p>âAnd what do you think that was?â Pippin asked at last, trying to speak lightly, but quavering a little. âIf it was a bird, it was one that I never heard in the Shire before.â</p>
<p>âIt was not bird or beast,â said Frodo. âIt was a call, or a signal â there were words in that cry, though I could not catch them. But no hobbit has such a voice.â</p>
<p>No more was said about it. They were all thinking of the Riders, but no one spoke of them. They were now reluctant either to stay or go on; but sooner or later they had got to get across the open country to the Ferry, and it was best to go sooner and in daylight. In a few moments they had shouldered their packs again and were off.</p>
<p>Before long the wood came to a sudden end. Wide grass-lands stretched before them. They now saw that they had, in fact, turned too much to the south. Away over the flats they could glimpse the low hill of Bucklebury across the River, but it was now to their left. Creeping cautiously out from the edge of the trees, they set off across the open as quickly as they could.</p>
<p>At first they felt afraid, away from the shelter of the wood. Far back behind them stood the high place where they had breakfasted. Frodo half expected to see the small distant figure of a horseman on the ridge dark against the sky; but there was no sign of one. The sun escaping from the breaking clouds, as it sank towards the hills they had left, was now shining brightly again. Their fear left them, though they still felt uneasy. But the land became steadily more tame and well-ordered. Soon they came into well-tended fields and meadows: there were hedges and gates and dikes for drainage. Everything seemed quiet and peaceful, just an ordinary corner of the Shire. Their spirits rose with every step. The line of the River grew nearer; and the Black Riders began to seem like phantoms of the woods now left far behind.</p>
<p>They passed along the edge of a huge turnip-field, and came to a stout gate. Beyond it a rutted lane ran between low well-laid hedges towards a distant clump of trees. Pippin stopped.</p>
<p>âI know these fields and this gate!â he said. âThis is Bamfurlong, old Farmer Maggotâs land. Thatâs his farm away there in the trees.â</p>
<p>âOne trouble after another!â said Frodo, looking nearly as much alarmed as if Pippin had declared the lane was the slot leading to a dragonâs den. The others looked at him in surprise.</p>
<p>âWhatâs wrong with old Maggot?â asked Pippin. âHeâs a good friend to all the Brandybucks. Of course heâs a terror to trespassers, and keeps ferocious dogs â but after all, folk down here are near the border and have to be more on their guard.â</p>
<p>âI know,â said Frodo. âBut all the same,â he added with a shamefaced laugh, âI am terrified of him and his dogs. I have avoided his farm for years and years. <p>Pippin laughed. âWell, itâs time you made it up. Especially if you are coming back to live in Buckland. Old Maggot is really a stout fellow â if you leave his mushrooms alone. <p>They went along the lane, until they saw the thatched roofs of a large house and farm-buildings peeping out among the trees ahead. <p>Suddenly as they drew nearer a terrific baying and barking broke out, and a loud voice was heard shouting: âGrip! Fang! Wolf! Come on, lads!â</p>
<p>Frodo and Sam stopped dead, but Pippin walked on a few paces. The gate opened and three huge dogs came pelting out into the lane, and dashed towards the travellers, barking fiercely. <p>Through the gate there now appeared a broad thick-set hobbit with a round red face. âHallo! Hallo! And who may you be, and what may you be wanting?â he asked.</p>
<p>âGood afternoon, Mr. Maggot!â said Pippin.</p>

<p>âWhat fellow do you mean?â asked Pippin.</p>
<p>âThen you havenât seen him?â said the farmer. âHe went up the lane towards the causeway not a long while back. He was a funny customer and asking funny questions. <p>It seemed plain that the farmer would tell them more, if allowed to do it in his own time and fashion, so they all accepted the invitation. âWhat about the dogs?â asked Frodo anxiously.</p>

</section><section><title><p>Chapter 5</p>
<p>A Conspiracy Unmasked</p>
</title><p>âNow we had better get home ourselves,â said Merry. Thereâs something funny about all this, I see; but it must wait till we get in.â</p>
<p>They turned down the Ferry lane, which was straight and well-kept and edged with large white-washed stones. In a hundred yards or so it brought them to the river-bank, where there was a broad wooden landing-stage. A large flat ferry-boat was moored beside it. The white bollards near the waterâs edge glimmered in the light of two lamps on high posts. Behind them the mists in the flat fields were now above the hedges; but the water before them was dark, with only a few curling wisps like steam among the reeds by the bank. <p>Merry led the pony over a gangway on to the ferry, and the others followed. Merry then pushed slowly off with a long pole. The Brandywine flowed slow and broad before them. On the other side the bank was steep, and up it a winding path climbed from the further landing. Lamps were twinkling there. Behind loomed up the Buck Hill; and out of it, through stray shrouds of mist, shone many round windows, yellow and red. They were the windows of Brandy Hall, the ancient home of the Brandybucks.</p>
<p>Long ago Gorhendad Oldbuck, head of the Oldbuck family, one of the oldest in the Marish or indeed in the Shire, had crossed the river, which was the original boundary of the land eastwards. He built (and excavated) Brandy Hall, changed his name to Brandybuck, and settled down to become master of what was virtually a small independent country. His family grew and grew, and after his days continued to grow, until Brandy Hall occupied the whole of the low hill, and had three large front-doors, many side-doors, and about a hundred windows. The Brandybucks and their numerous dependants then began to burrow, and later to build, all round about. That was the origin of Buckland, a thickly inhabited strip between the river and the Old Forest, a sort of colony from the Shire. Its chief village was Bucklebury, clustering in the banks and slopes behind Brandy Hall.</p>
<p>The people in the Marish were friendly with the Bucklanders, and the authority of the Master of the Hall (as the head of the Brandybuck family was called) was still acknowledged by the farmers between Stock and Rushey. But most of the folk of the old Shire regarded the Bucklanders as peculiar, half foreigners as it were. Though, as a matter of fact, they were not very different from the other hobbits of the Four Farthings. Except in one point: they were fond of boats, and some of them could swim.</p>
<p>Their land was originally unprotected from the East; but on that side they had built a hedge: the High Hay. It had been planted many generations ago, and was now thick and tall, for it was constantly tended. It ran all the way from Brandywine Bridge, in a big loop curving away from the river, to Haysend (where the Withywindle flowed out of the Forest into the Brandywine): well over twenty miles from end to end. But, of course, it was not a complete protection. The Forest drew close to the hedge in many places. The Bucklanders kept their doors locked after dark, and that also was not usual in the Shire.</p>
<p>The ferry-boat moved slowly across the water. The Buckland shore drew nearer. Sam was the only member of the party who had not been over the river before. He had a strange feeling as the slow gurgling stream slipped by: his old life lay behind in the mists, dark adventure lay in front. He scratched his head, and for a moment had a passing wish that Mr. Frodo could have gone on living quietly at Bag End.</p>
<p>The four hobbits stepped off the ferry. Merry was tying it up, and Pippin was already leading the pony up the path, when Sam (who had been looking back, as if to take farewell of the Shire) said in a hoarse whisper:</p>
<p>âLook back, Mr. Frodo! Do you see anything?â</p>
<p>On the far stage, under the distant lamps, they could just make out a figure: it looked like a dark black bundle left behind. But as they looked it seemed to move and sway this way and that, as if searching the ground. It then crawled, or went crouching, back into the gloom beyond the lamps.</p>
<p>âWhat in the Shire is that?â exclaimed Merry.</p>
<p>âSomething that is following us,â said Frodo. âBut donât ask any more now! Letâs get away at once!â They hurried up the path to the top of the bank, but when they looked back the far shore was shrouded in mist, and nothing could be seen.</p>

<p>It was some distance from the Brandywine to Frodoâs new house at Crickhollow. <p>At last they came to a narrow gate in a thick hedge. <p>As they walked up the green path from the gate no light was visible; the windows were dark and shuttered. Frodo knocked on the door, and Fatty Bolger opened it. A friendly light streamed out. <p>Frodo opened his mouth and shut it again. His look of surprise was so comical that they laughed. âDear old Frodo!â said Pippin. âDid you really think you had thrown dust in all our eyes? <p>âBut I must go,â said Frodo. âIt cannot be helped, dear friends. It is wretched for us all, but it is no use your trying to keep me. Since you have guessed so much, please help me and do not hinder me!â</p>

<p>It was made on the model of the dwarf-song that started Bilbo on his adventure long ago, and went to the same tune:</p>
<poem><stanza><v>Farewell we call to hearth and hall!</v><v>Though wind may blow and rain may fall,</v><v>We must away ere break of day</v><v>Far over wood and mountain tall.</v></stanza><stanza><v>To Rivendell, where Elves yet dwell</v><v>In glades beneath the misty fell,</v><v>Through moor and waste we ride in haste,</v><v>And whither then we cannot tell.</v></stanza><stanza><v>With foes ahead, behind us dread,</v><v>Beneath the sky shall be our bed,</v><v>Until at last our toil be passed,</v><v>Our journey done, our errand sped.</v></stanza><stanza><v>We must away! <p>Fond as he was of Frodo, Fatty Bolger had no desire to leave the Shire, nor to see what lay outside it. <p>âExcellent!â said Frodo, when he understood the plan. âWe could not have left any message behind for Gandalf otherwise. <p>When at last he had got to bed, Frodo could not sleep for some time. His legs ached. He. was glad that he was riding in the morning. <p>Then he heard a noise in the distance. At first he thought it was a great wind coming over the leaves of the forest. </section><section><title><p>Chapter 6</p>
<p>The Old Forest</p>
</title><p>Frodo woke suddenly. It was still dark in the room. Merry was standing there with a candle in one hand, and banging on the door with the other. âAll right! What is it?â said Frodo, still shaken and bewildered.</p>
<p>âWhat is it!â cried Merry. âIt is time to get up. It is half past four and very foggy. Come on! Sam is already getting breakfast ready. Even Pippin is up. <p>Soon after six oâclock the five hobbits were ready to start. Fatty Bolger was still yawning. They stole quietly out of the house. Merry went in front leading a laden pony, and took his way along a path that went through a spinney behind the house, and then cut across several fields. The leaves of trees were glistening, and every twig was dripping; the grass was grey with cold dew. Everything was still, and far-away noises seemed near and clear: fowls chattering in a yard, someone closing a door of a distant house.</p>
<p>In their shed they found the ponies; sturdy little beasts of the kind loved by hobbits, not speedy, but good for a long dayâs work. They mounted, and soon they were riding off into the mist, which seemed to open reluctantly before them and close forbiddingly behind them. After riding for about an hour, slowly and without talking, they saw the Hedge looming suddenly ahead. It was tall and netted over with silver cobwebs. âHow are you going to get through this?â asked Fredegar. âFollow me!â said Merry, âand you will see.â He turned to the left along the Hedge, and soon they came to a point where it bent inwards, running along the lip of a hollow. A cutting had been made, at some distance from the Hedge, and went sloping gently down into the ground. It had walls of brick at the sides, which rose steadily, until suddenly they arched over and formed a tunnel that dived deep under the Hedge and came out in the hollow on the other side.</p>
<p>Here Fatty Bolger halted. âGood-bye, Frodo!â he said. âI wish you were not going into the Forest. I only hope you will not need rescuing before the day is out. But good luck to you â today and every day!â</p>
<p>âIf there are no worse things ahead than the Old Forest, I shall be lucky,â said Frodo. âTell Gandalf to hurry along the East Road: we shall soon be back on it and going as fast as we can.â âGood-bye!â they cried, and rode down the slope and disappeared from Fredegarâs sight into the tunnel.</p>
<p>It was dark and damp. At the far end it was closed by a gate of thick-set iron bars. Merry got down and unlocked the gate, and when they had all passed through he pushed it to again. It shut with a clang, and the lock clicked. The sound was ominous.</p>
<p>âThere!â said Merry. âYou have left the Shire, and are now outside, and on the edge of the Old Forest.â</p>
<p>âAre the stories about it true?â asked Pippin.</p>
<p>âI donât know what stories you mean,â Merry answered. âIf you mean the old bogey-stories Fattyâs nurses used to tell him, about goblins and wolves and things of that sort, I should say no. And the trees do not like strangers. They watch you. They are usually content merely to watch you, as long as daylight lasts, and donât do much. Occasionally the most unfriendly ones may drop a branch, or stick a root out, or grasp at you with a long trailer. But at night things can be most alarming, or so I am told. I thought all the trees were whispering to each other, passing news and plots along in an unintelligible language; and the branches swayed and groped without any wind. After that the trees gave up the attack, but they became very unfriendly. There is still a wide bare space not far inside where the bonfire was made.â</p>
<p>âIs it only the trees that are dangerous?â asked Pippin.</p>
<p>âThere are various queer things living deep in the Forest, and on the far side,â said Merry, âor at least I have heard so; but I have never seen any of them. But something makes paths. Whenever one comes inside one finds open tracks; but they seem to shift and change from time to time in a queer fashion. <p>The hobbits now left the tunnel-gate and rode across the wide hollow. On the far side was a faint path leading up on to the floor of the Forest, a hundred yards and more beyond the Hedge; but it vanished as soon as it brought them under the trees. Looking back they could see the dark line of the Hedge through the stems of trees that were already thick about them. Looking ahead they could see only tree-trunks of innumerable sizes and shapes: straight or bent, twisted, leaning, squat or slender, smooth or gnarled and branched; and all the stems were green or grey with moss and slimy, shaggy growths.</p>
<p>Merry alone seemed fairly cheerful. âYou had better lead on and find that path,â Frodo said to him. âDonât let us lose one another, or forget which way the Hedge lies!â</p>
<p>They picked a way among the trees, and their ponies plodded along, carefully avoiding the many writhing and interlacing roots. There was no undergrowth. The ground was rising steadily, and as they went forward it seemed that the trees became taller, darker, and thicker. There was no sound, except an occasional drip of moisture falling through the still leaves. The feeling steadily grew, until they found themselves looking up quickly, or glancing back over their shoulders, as if they expected a sudden blow.</p>
<p>There was not as yet any sign of a path, and the trees seemed constantly to bar their way. Pippin suddenly felt that he could not bear it any longer, and without warning let out a shout. âOi! Oi!â he cried. âI am not going to do anything. Just let me pass through, will you!â</p>
<p>The others halted startled; but the cry fell as if muffled by a heavy curtain. There was no echo or answer though the wood seemed to become more crowded and more watchful than before.</p>
<p>âI should not shout, if I were you,â said Merry. It does more harm than good.â</p>
<p>Frodo began to wonder if it were possible to find a way through, and if he had been right to make the others come into this abominable wood. <p>âWell, well!â he said. âThese trees <emphasis>do</emphasis> shift. There is the Bonfire Glade in front of us (or I hope so), but the path to it seems to have moved away!â</p>
<p>The light grew clearer as they went forward. Suddenly they came out of the trees and found themselves in a wide circular space. There was sky above them, blue and clear to their surprise, for down under the Forest-roof they had not been able to see the rising morning and the lifting of the mist. The sun was not, however, high enough yet to shine down into the clearing, though its light was on the tree-tops. No tree grew there, only rough grass and many tall plants: stalky and faded hemlocks and wood-parsley, fire-weed seeding into fluffy ashes, and rampant nettles and thistles.
