<p>Inside in the hall there was piled a large assortment of packages and parcels and small articles of furniture. On every item there was a label tied. There were several labels of this sort:</p>
<p><emphasis>For ADELARD TOOK, for his VERY OWN, from Bilbo</emphasis>, on an umbrella. Adelard had carried off many unlabelled ones.</p>
<p><emphasis>For DORA BAGGINS in memory of a LONG correspondence, with love from Bilbo</emphasis>, on a large waste-paper basket. Dora was Drogoâs sister and the eldest surviving female relative of Bilbo and Frodo; she was ninety-nine, and had written reams of good advice for more than half a century.</p>
<p><emphasis>For MILO BURROWS, hoping it will be useful, from B.B</emphasis>., on a gold pen and ink-bottle. Milo never answered letters.</p>
<p><emphasis>For ANGELICAâS use, from Uncle Bilbo</emphasis>, on a round convex mirror. She was a young Baggins, and too obviously considered her face shapely.</p>
<p><emphasis>For the collection of HUGO BRACEGIRDLE, from a contributor</emphasis>, on an (empty) book-case. Hugo was a great borrower of books, and worse than usual at returning them.</p>
<p><emphasis>For LOBELIA SACKVILLE-BAGGINS, as a PRESENT</emphasis>, on a case of silver spoons. Bilbo believed that she had acquired a good many of his spoons, while he was away on his former journey. Lobelia knew that quite well. When she arrived later in the day, she took the point at once, but she also took the spoons.</p>
<p>This is only a small selection of the assembled presents. Bilboâs residence had got rather cluttered up with things in the course of his long life. It was a tendency of hobbit-holes to get cluttered up: for which the custom of giving so many birthday-presents was largely responsible. Not, of course, that the birthday-presents were always <emphasis>new</emphasis>, there were one or two old <emphasis>mathoms</emphasis> of forgotten uses that had circulated all around the district; but Bilbo had usually given new presents, and kept those that he received. The old hole was now being cleared a little.</p>
<p>Every one of the various parting gifts had labels, written out personally by Bilbo, and several had some point, or some joke. But, of course, most of the things were given where they would be wanted and welcome. The poorer hobbits, and especially those of Bagshot Row, did very well. Old Gaffer Gamgee got two sacks of potatoes, a new spade, a woollen waistcoat, and a bottle of ointment for creaking joints. Old Rory Brandybuck, in return for much hospitality, got a dozen bottles of Old Winyards: a strong red wine from the Southfarthing, and now quite mature, as it had been laid down by Bilboâs father. Rory quite forgave Bilbo, and voted him a capital fellow after the first bottle.</p>
<p>There was plenty of everything left for Frodo. And, of course, all the chief treasures, as well as the books, pictures, and more than enough furniture, were left in his possession. There was, however, no sign nor mention of money or jewellery: not a penny-piece or a glass bead was given away.</p>
<p>Frodo had a very trying time that afternoon. A false rumour that the whole household was being distributed free spread like wildfire; and before long the place was packed with people who had no business there, but could not be kept out. Labels got torn off and mixed, and quarrels broke out. Some people tried to do swaps and deals in the hall; and others tried to make <emphasis>off</emphasis> with minor items not addressed to them, or with anything that seemed unwanted or unwatched. The road to the gate was blocked with barrows and handcarts.</p>
<p>In the middle of the commotion the Sackville-Bagginses arrived. Frodo had retired for a while and left his friend Merry Brandybuck to keep an eye on things. When Otho loudly demanded to see Frodo, Merry bowed politely.</p>
<p>âHe is indisposed,â he said. âHe is resting.â</p>
<p>âHiding, you mean,â said Lobelia. âAnyway we want to see him and we mean to see him. Just go and tell him so!â</p>
<p>Merry left them a long while in the hall, and they had time to discover their parting gift of spoons. It did not improve their tempers. Eventually they were shown into the study. Frodo was sitting at a table with a lot of papers in front of him. He looked indisposed â to see Sackville-Bagginses at any rate; and he stood up, fidgeting with something in his pocket. <p>The Sackville-Bagginses were rather offensive. They began by offering him bad bargain-prices (as between friends) for various valuable and unlabelled things. When Frodo replied that only the things specially directed by Bilbo were being given away, they said the whole affair was very fishy.</p>
<p>âOnly one thing is clear to me,â said Otho, âand that is that you are doing exceedingly well out of it. I insist on seeing the will.â</p>
<p>Otho would have been Bilboâs heir, but for the adoption of Frodo. He read the will carefully and snorted. It was, unfortunately, very clear and correct (according to the legal customs of hobbits, which demand among other things seven signatures of witnesses in red ink).</p>
<p>âFoiled again!â he said to his wife. âAnd after waiting <emphasis>sixty</emphasis> years. Spoons? Fiddlesticks!â He snapped his fingers under Frodoâs nose and slumped off. <p>âYouâll live to regret it, young fellow! Why didnât you go too? You donât belong here; youâre no Baggins â you â youâre a Brandybuck!â</p>
<p>âDid you hear that, Merry? That was an insult, if you like,â said Frodo as he shut the door on her.</p>
<p>âIt was a compliment,â said Merry Brandybuck, âand so, of course, not true.â</p>
<p>Then they went round the hole, and evicted three young hobbits (two Boffins and a Bolger) who were knocking holes in the walls of one of the cellars. The legend of Bilboâs gold excited both curiosity and hope; for legendary gold (mysteriously obtained, if not positively ill-gotten), is, as every one knows, any oneâs for the finding â unless the search is interrupted.</p>
<p>When he had overcome Sancho and pushed him out, Frodo collapsed on a chair in the hall. <p>He had hardly sat down, when there came a soft knock at the front-door. âLobelia again most likely,â he thought. âShe must have thought of something really nasty, and have come back again to say it. It can wait.â</p>
<p>He went on with his tea. The knock was repeated, much louder, but he took no notice. Suddenly the wizardâs head appeared at the window.</p>
<p>âIf you donât let me in, Frodo, I shall blow your door right down your hole and out through the hill,â he said.</p>

<p>âThen I forgive you. But I saw her some time ago, driving a pony-trap towards Bywater with a face that would have curdled new milk.â</p>
<p>âShe had already nearly curdled me. Honestly, I nearly tried on Bilboâs ring. I longed to disappear.â</p>

<p>âWell, what about it?â</p>
<p>âWhat do you know already?â</p>
<p>âOnly what Bilbo told me. I have heard his story: how he found it, and how he used it: on his journey, I mean.â</p>
<p>âWhich story, I wonder,â said Gandalf.</p>
<p>âOh, not what he told the dwarves and put in his book,â said Frodo. âHe told me the true story soon after I came to live here. <p>âThatâs interesting,â said Gandalf. âWell, what did you think of it all?â</p>
<p>âIf you mean, inventing all that about a "present", well, I thought the true story much more likely, and I couldnât see the point of altering it at all. It was very unlike Bilbo to do so, anyway; and I thought it rather odd.â</p>
<p>âSo did I. But odd things may happen to people that have such treasures â if they use them. Let it be a warning to you to be very careful with it. It may have other powers than just making you vanish when you wish to.â</p>
<p>âI donât understand,â said Frodo.</p>
<p>âNeither do I,â answered the wizard. âI have merely begun to wonder about the ring, especially since last night. No need to worry. <p>âYou are very mysterious! What are you afraid of?â</p>
<p>âI am not certain, so I will say no more. I may be able to tell you something when I come back. I am going off at once: so this is good-bye for the present.â He got up.</p>
<p>âAt once!â cried Frodo. âWhy, I thought you were staying on for at least a week. I was looking forward to your help.â</p>
<p>âI did mean to â but I have had to change my mind. I may be away for a good while; but Iâll come and see you again, as soon as I can. Expect me when you see me! I shall slip in quietly. <p>âSome people!â exclaimed Frodo. âYou mean Otho and Lobelia. How abominable! <p>âSo do I,â said Gandalf. âAnd I wonder many other things. Good-bye now! Take care of yourself! Look out for me, especially at unlikely times! Good-bye!â</p>
<p>Frodo saw him to the door. He gave a final wave of his hand, and walked off at a surprising pace; but Frodo thought the old wizard looked unusually bent, almost as if he was carrying a great weight. The evening was closing in, and his cloaked figure quickly vanished into the twilight. Frodo did not see him again for a long time.</p>
</section><section><title><p>Chapter 2</p>
<p>The Shadow of the Past</p>
</title><p>The talk did not die down in nine or even ninety-nine days. The second disappearance of Mr. Bilbo Baggins was discussed in Hobbiton, and indeed all over the Shire, for a year and a day, and was remembered much longer than that. It became a fireside-story for young hobbits; and eventually Mad Baggins, who used to vanish with a bang and a flash and reappear with bags of jewels and gold, became a favourite character of legend and lived on long after all the true events were forgotten.</p>
<p>But in the meantime, the general opinion in the neighbourhood was that Bilbo, who had always been rather cracked, had at last gone quite mad, and had run off into the Blue. There he had undoubtedly fallen into a pool or a river and come to a tragic, but hardly an untimely, end. The blame was mostly laid on Gandalf.</p>
<p>âIf only that dratted wizard will leave young Frodo alone, perhaps heâll settle down and grow some hobbit-sense,â they said. And to all appearance the wizard did leave Frodo alone, and he did settle down, but the growth of hobbit-sense was not very noticeable. Indeed, he at once began to carry on Bilboâs reputation for oddity. He refused to go into mourning; and the next year he gave a party in honour of Bilboâs hundred-and-twelfth birthday, which he called Hundred-weight Feast. But that was short of the mark, for twenty guests were invited and there were several meals at which it snowed food and rained drink, as hobbits say.</p>
<p>Some people were rather shocked; but Frodo kept up the custom of giving Bilboâs Birthday Party year after year until they got used to it. He said that he did not think Bilbo was dead. When they asked: âWhere is he then?â he shrugged his shoulders.</p>
<p>He lived alone, as Bilbo had done; but he had a good many friends, especially among the younger hobbits (mostly descendants of the Old Took) who had as children been fond of Bilbo and often in and out of Bag End. Folco Boffin and Fredegar Bolger were two of these; but his closest friends were Peregrin Took (usually called Pippin), and Merry Brandybuck (his real name was Meriadoc, but that was seldom remembered). Frodo went tramping all over the Shire with them; but more often he wandered by himself, and to the amazement of sensible folk he was sometimes seen far from home walking in the hills and woods under the starlight. Merry and Pippin suspected that he visited the Elves at times, as Bilbo had done.</p>
<p>As time went on, people began to notice that Frodo also showed signs of good âpreservationâ: outwardly he retained the appearance of a robust and energetic hobbit just out of his tweens. âSome folk have all the luck,â they said; but it was not until Frodo approached the usually more sober age of fifty that they began to think it queer.</p>
<p>Frodo himself, after the first shock, found that being his own master and <emphasis>the</emphasis> Mr. Baggins of Bag End was rather pleasant. For some years he was quite happy and did not worry much about the future. But half unknown to himself the regret that he had not gone with Bilbo was steadily growing. He found himself wondering at times, especially in the autumn, about the wild lands, and strange visions of mountains that he had never seen came into his dreams. He began to say to himself: âPerhaps I shall cross the River myself one day.â To which the other half of his mind always replied: âNot yet.â</p>
<p>So it went on, until his forties were running out, and his fiftieth birthday was drawing near: fifty was a number that he felt was somehow significant (or ominous); it was at any rate at that age that adventure had suddenly befallen Bilbo. Frodo began to feel restless, and the old paths seemed too well-trodden. He looked at maps, and wondered what lay beyond their edges: maps made in the Shire showed mostly white spaces beyond its borders. He took to wandering further afield and more often by himself; and Merry and his other friends watched him anxiously. Often he was seen walking and talking with the strange wayfarers that began at this time to appear in the Shire.</p>
<p>There were rumours of strange things happening in the world outside; and as Gandalf had not at that time appeared or sent any message for several years, Frodo gathered all the news he could. Elves, who seldom walked in the Shire, could now be seen passing westward through the woods in the evening, passing and not returning; but they were leaving Middle-earth and were no longer concerned with its troubles. There were, however, dwarves on the road in unusual numbers. The ancient East-West Road ran through the Shire to its end at the Grey Havens, and dwarves had always used it on their way to their mines in the Blue Mountains. They were the hobbitsâ chief source of news from distant parts â if they wanted any: as a rule dwarves said little and hobbits asked no more. But now Frodo often met strange dwarves of far countries, seeking refuge in the West. They were troubled, and some spoke in whispers of the Enemy and of the Land of Mordor.</p>
<p>That name the hobbits only knew in legends of the dark past, like a shadow in the background of their memories; but it was ominous and disquieting. It seemed that the evil power in Mirkwood had been driven out by the White Council only to reappear in greater strength in the old strongholds of Mordor. The Dark Tower had been rebuilt, it was said. From there the power was spreading far and wide, and away far east and south there were wars and growing fear. Orcs were multiplying again in the mountains. Trolls were abroad, no longer dull-witted, but cunning and armed with dreadful weapons. And there were murmured hints of creatures more terrible than all these, but they had no name.</p>
<p>Little of all this, of course, reached the ears of ordinary hobbits. But even the deafest and most stay-at-home began to hear queer tales; and those whose business took them to the borders saw strange things. The conversation in <emphasis>The Green Dragon</emphasis> at Bywater, one evening in the spring of Frodoâs fiftieth year, showed that even in the comfortable heart of the Shire rumours had been heard, though most hobbits still laughed at them.</p>
<p>Sam Gamgee was sitting in one corner near the fire, and opposite him was Ted Sandyman, the millerâs son; and there were various other rustic hobbits listening to their talk.</p>
<p>âQueer things you do hear these days, to be sure,â said Sam.</p>
<p>âAh,â said Ted, âyou do, if you listen. But I can hear fireside-tales and childrenâs stories at home, if I want to.â</p>
<p>âNo doubt you can,â retorted Sam, âand I daresay thereâs more truth in some of them than you reckon. Who invented the stories anyway? Take dragons now.â</p>
<p>âNo thank âee,â said Ted, âI wonât. I heard tell of them when I was a youngster, but thereâs no call to believe in them now. Thereâs only one Dragon in Bywater, and thatâs Green,â he said, getting a general laugh.</p>
<p>âAll right,â said Sam, laughing with the rest. âBut what about these Tree-men, these giants, as you might call them? They do say that one bigger than a tree was seen up away beyond the North Moors not long back.â</p>
<p>âWhoâs <emphasis>they</emphasis> ?â</p>
<p>âMy cousin Hal for one. He works for Mr. Boffin at Overhill and goes up to the Northfarthing for the hunting. He <emphasis>saw</emphasis> one.â</p>
<p>âSays he did, perhaps. Your Halâs always saying heâs seen things; and maybe he sees things that ainât there.â</p>
<p>âBut this one was as big as an elm tree, and walking â walking seven yards to a stride, if it was an inch.â</p>
<p>âThen I bet it wasnât an inch. What he saw <emphasis>was</emphasis> an elm tree, as like as not.â</p>
<p>âBut this one was <emphasis>walking</emphasis>, I tell you; and there ainât no elm tree on the North Moors.â</p>
<p>âThen Hal canât have seen one,â said Ted. There was some laughing and clapping: the audience seemed to think that Ted had scored a point.</p>
<p>âAll the same,â said Sam, âyou canât deny that others besides our Halfast have seen queer folk crossing the Shire â crossing it, mind you: there are more that are turned back at the borders. The Bounders have never been so busy before.</p>
<p>âAnd Iâve heard tell that Elves are moving west. <p>âThey are sailing, sailing, sailing over the Sea, they are going into the West and leaving us,â said Sam, half chanting the words, shaking his head sadly and solemnly. But Ted laughed.</p>
<p>âWell, that isnât anything new, if you believe the old tales. And I donât see what it matters to me or you. Let them sail! But I warrant you havenât seen them doing it; nor any one else in the Shire.â</p>
<p>âWell I donât know,â said Sam thoughtfully. He believed he had once seen an Elf in the woods, and still hoped to see more one day. <p>âOh, theyâre both cracked,â said Ted. âLeastways old Bilbo was cracked, and Frodoâs cracking. If thatâs where you get your news from, youâll never want for moonshine. Well, friends, Iâm off home. Your good health!â He drained his mug and went out noisily.</p>
<p>Sam sat silent and said no more. He had a good deal to think about. For one thing, there was a lot to do up in the Bag End garden, and he would have a busy day tomorrow, if the weather cleared. <p>It was early April and the sky was now clearing after heavy rain. The sun was down, and a cool pale evening was quietly fading into night. He walked home under the early stars through Hobbiton and up the Hill, whistling softly and thoughtfully.</p>
<p>It was just at this time that Gandalf reappeared after his long absence. For three years after the Party he had been away. Then he paid Frodo a brief visit, and after taking a good look at him he went off again. <p>Then suddenly his visits had ceased. <p>Frodo welcomed his old friend with surprise and great delight. They looked hard at one another.</p>
<p>âAh well eh?â said Gandalf. âYou look the same as ever, Frodo!â</p>
<p>âSo do you,â Frodo replied; but secretly he thought that Gandalf looked older and more careworn. He pressed him for news of himself and of the wide world, and soon they were deep in talk, and they stayed up far into the night.</p>
<p>Next morning after a late breakfast, the wizard was sitting with Frodo by the open window of the study. A bright fire was on the hearth, but the sun was warm, and the wind was in the South. <p>Gandalf was thinking of a spring, nearly eighty years before, when Bilbo had run out of Bag End without a handkerchief. <empty-line/><image l:href="#gandalf_frodo.jpg"/><p>He was smoking now in silence, for Frodo was sitting still, deep in thought. Even in the light of morning he felt the dark shadow of the tidings that Gandalf had brought. At last he broke the silence.</p>
<p>âLast night you began to tell me strange things about my ring, Gandalf,â he said. âAnd then you stopped, because you said that such matters were best left until daylight. <p>âIn many ways,â answered the wizard. It is far more powerful than I ever dared to think at first, so powerful that in the end it would utterly overcome anyone of mortal race who possessed it. It would possess him.</p>
<p>âIn Eregion long ago many Elven-rings were made, magic rings as you call them, and they were, of course, of various kinds: some more potent and some less. <p>âA mortal, Frodo, who keeps one of the Great Rings, does not die, but he does not grow or obtain more life, he merely continues, until at last every minute is a weariness. <p>âHow terrifying!â said Frodo. There was another long silence. The sound of Sam Gamgee cutting the lawn came in from the garden.</p>

<p>âBilbo knew no more than he told you, I am sure,â said Gandalf. âHe would certainly never have passed on to you anything that he thought would be a danger, even though I promised to look after you. <p>âYes, he warned me of that in his last letter,â said Frodo, âso I have always kept it on its chain.â</p>
<p>âVery wise,â said Gandalf. âBut as for his long life, Bilbo never connected it with the ring at all. He took all the credit for that to himself, and he was very proud of it. <p>âHow long have you known all this?â asked Frodo again.</p>

<p>âWhen did I first begin to guess?â he mused, searching back in memory. âLet me see â it was in the year that the White Council drove the dark power from Mirkwood, just before the Battle of Five Armies, that Bilbo found his ring. </section><section><title><p>Chapter 3</p>
<p>Three is Company</p>
</title><p>âYou ought to go quietly, and you ought to go soon,â said Gandalf. Two or three weeks had passed, and still Frodo made no sign of getting ready to go.</p>

<p>To tell the truth, he was very reluctant to start, now that it had come to the point. <p>He looked at Frodo and smiled. âVery well,â he said. âI think that will do â but it must not be any later. I am getting very anxious. <p>One summerâs evening an astonishing piece of news reached the <emphasis>Ivy Bush</emphasis> and <emphasis>Green Dragon</emphasis>. <p>Just why Mr. Frodo was selling his beautiful hole was even more debatable than the price. <p>Gandalf stayed in the Shire for over two months. <p>At first Frodo was a good deal disturbed, and wondered often what Gandalf could have heard; but his uneasiness wore off, and in the fine weather he forgot his troubles for a while. <p>Autumn was well under way before Frodo began to worry about Gandalf again. September was passing and there was still no news of him. <p>The four younger hobbits were, however, in high spirits, and the party soon became very cheerful in spite of Gandalfâs absence. <p>The next morning they were busy packing another cart with the remainder of the luggage. <p>Folco went home after lunch, but Pippin remained behind. Frodo was restless and anxious, listening in vain for a sound of Gandalf. He decided to wait until nightfall. <p>âI shall get myself a bit into training, too,â he said, looking at himself in a dusty mirror in the half-empty hall. He had not done any strenuous walking for a long time, and the reflection looked rather flabby, he thought.</p>
<p>After lunch, the Sackville-Bagginses, Lobelia and her sandy-haired son, Lotho, turned up, much to Frodoâs annoyance. âOurs at last!â said Lobelia, as she stepped inside. <p>He took his own tea with Pippin and Sam Gamgee in the kitchen. <p>The sun went down. Bag End seemed sad and gloomy and dishevelled. Frodo wandered round the familiar rooms, and saw the light of the sunset fade on the walls, and shadows creep out of the corners. <p>The sky was clear and the stars were growing bright. âItâs going to be a fine night,â he said aloud. âThatâs good for a beginning. I feel like walking. <p>âNo, Mr. Baggins has gone away. Went this morning, and my Sam went with him: anyway all his stuff went. Yes, sold out and gone, I tellâee. Why? Whyâs none of my business, or yours. Where to? <p>Footsteps went away down the Hill. <p>Frodo shut and locked the round door, and gave the key to Sam. âRun down with this to your home, Sam!â he said. âThen cut along the Row and meet us as quick as you can at the gate in the lane beyond the meadows. <p>âWell, now weâre off at last!â said Frodo. <p>At the bottom of the Hill on its western side they came to the gate opening on to a narrow lane. There they halted and adjusted the straps of their packs. <p>âI am sure you have given me all the heaviest stuff,â said Frodo. âI pity snails, and all that carry their homes on their backs.â</p>

<p>After some time they crossed the Water, west of Hobbiton, by a narrow plank-bridge. The stream was there no more than a winding black ribbon, bordered with leaning alder-trees. <p>When they had walked for about three hours they rested. The night was clear, cool, and starry, but smoke-like wisps of mist were creeping up the hill-sides from the streams and deep meadows. <p>After a while they plunged into a deeply cloven track between tall trees that rustled their dry leaves in the night. It was very dark. <p>Just over the top of the hill they came on the patch of fir-wood. Leaving the road they went into the deep resin-scented darkness of the trees, and gathered dead sticks and cones to make a fire. <p>When their breakfast was over, and their packs all trussed up again, it was after ten oâclock, and the day was beginning to turn fine and hot. <p>Round the corner came a black horse, no hobbit-pony but a full-sized horse; and on it sat a large man, who seemed to crouch in the saddle, wrapped in a great black cloak and hood, so that only his boots in the high stirrups showed below; his face was shadowed and invisible.</p>

<p>Twilight was about them as they crept back to the lane. The West wind was sighing in the branches. Leaves were whispering. Soon the road began to fall gently but steadily into the dusk. <poem><stanza><v>Upon the hearth the fire is red,</v><v>Beneath the roof there is a bed;</v><v>But not yet weary are our feet,</v><v>Still round the corner we may meet</v><v>A sudden tree or standing stone</v><v>That none have seen but we alone.</v></stanza><stanza><v>Tree and flower and leaf and grass,</v><v>Let them pass! It showed grey and pale, a line of fading light through the wood. Above it the stars were thick in the dim sky, but there was no moon.</p>
<p>The sound of hoofs stopped. As Frodo watched he saw something dark pass across the lighter space between two trees, and then halt. It looked like the black shade of a horse led by a smaller black shadow. The black shadow stood close to the point where they had left the path, and it swayed from side to side. Frodo thought he heard the sound of snuffling. The shadow bent to the ground, and then began to crawl towards him.</p>
<p>Once more the desire to slip on the Ring came over Frodo; but this time it was stronger than before. So strong that, almost before he realized what he was doing, his hand was groping in his pocket. But at that moment there came a sound like mingled song and laughter. Clear voices rose and fell in the starlit air. The black shadow straightened up and retreated. It climbed on to the shadowy horse and seemed to vanish across the lane into the darkness on the other side. Frodo breathed again.</p>
<p>âElves!â exclaimed Sam in a hoarse whisper. âElves, sir!â He would have burst out of the trees and dashed off towards the voices, if they had not pulled him back.</p>
<p>âYes, it is Elves,â said Frodo. âOne can meet them sometimes in the Woody End. They donât live in the Shire, but they wander into it in Spring and Autumn, out of their own lands away beyond the Tower Hills. I am thankful that they do! You did not see, but that Black Rider stopped just here and was actually crawling towards us when the song began. As soon as he heard the voices he slipped away.â</p>
<p>âWhat about the Elves?â said Sam, too excited to trouble about the rider. âCanât we go and see them?â</p>
<p>âListen! They are coming this way,â said Frodo. âWe have only to wait.â The singing drew nearer. One clear voice rose now above the others. It was singing in the fair elven-tongue, of which Frodo knew only a little, and the others knew nothing. Yet the sound blending with the melody seemed to shape itself in their thought into words which they only partly understood. This was the song as Frodo heard it:</p>
<poem><stanza><v>Snow-white! Snow-white! O Lady clear!</v><v>O Queen beyond the Western Seas!</v><v>O Light to us that wander here</v><v>Amid the world of woven trees!</v></stanza><stanza><v>Gilthoniel! O Elbereth!</v><v>Clear are thy eyes and bright thy breath!</v><v>Snow-white! Snow-white! We sing to thee</v><v>In a far land beyond the Sea.</v></stanza><stanza><v>O stars that in the Sunless Year</v><v>With shining hand by her were sawn,</v><v>In windy fields now bright and clear</v><v>We see your silver blossom blown!</v></stanza><stanza><v>O Elbereth! Gilthoniel!</v><v>We still remember, we who dwell</v><v>In this far land beneath the trees,</v><v>Thy starlight on the Western Seas.</v></stanza></poem><p>The song ended. âThese are High Elves! They spoke the name of Elbereth!â said Frodo in amazement, âFew of that fairest folk are ever seen in the Shire. Not many now remain in Middle-earth, east of the Great Sea. This is indeed a strange chance!â</p>
<p>The hobbits sat in shadow by the wayside. Before long the Elves came down the lane towards the valley. They passed slowly, and the hobbits could see the starlight glimmering on their hair and in their eyes. They bore no lights, yet as they walked a shimmer, like the light of the moon above the rim of the hills before it rises, seemed to fall about their feet. They were now silent, and as the last Elf passed he turned and looked towards the hobbits and laughed.</p>
<p>âHail, Frodo!â he cried. âYou are abroad late. Or are you perhaps lost?â Then he called aloud to the others, and all the company stopped and gathered round.</p>
<p>âThis is indeed wonderful!â they said. âThree hobbits in a wood at night! We have not seen such a thing since Bilbo went away. What is the meaning of it?â</p>
<p>âThe meaning of it, fair people,â said Frodo, âis simply that we seem to be going the same way as you are. I like walking under the stars. But I would welcome your company.â</p>
<p>âBut we have no need of other company, and hobbits are so dull,â they laughed. âAnd how do you know that we go the same way as you, for you do not know whither we are going?â</p>
<p>âAnd how do you know my name?â asked Frodo in return.</p>
<p>âWe know many things,â they said. âWe have seen you often before with Bilbo, though you may not have seen us.â</p>
<p>âWho are you, and who is your lord?â asked Frodo.</p>
<p>âI am Gildor,â answered their leader, the Elf who had first hailed him. âGildor Inglorion of the House of Finrod. We are Exiles, and most of our kindred have long ago departed and we too are now only tarrying here a while, ere we return over the Great Sea. But some of our kinsfolk dwell still in peace in Rivendell. Come now, Frodo, tell us what you are doing? For we see that there is some shadow of fear upon you.â</p>
<p>âO Wise People!â interrupted Pippin eagerly. âTell us about the Black Riders!â</p>
<p>âBlack Riders?â they said in low voices. âWhy do you ask about Black Riders?â</p>
<p>âBecause two Black Riders have overtaken us today, or one has done so twice,â said Pippin; âonly a little while ago he slipped away as you drew near.â</p>
<p>The Elves did not answer at once, but spoke together softly in their own tongue. At length Gildor turned to the hobbits. âWe will not speak of this here,â he said. âWe think you had best come now with us. It is not our custom, but for this time we will lake you on our road, and you shall lodge with us tonight, if you will.â</p>
<p>âO Fair Folk! This is good fortune beyond my hope,â said Pippin. Sam was speechless. âI thank you indeed, Gildor Inglorion,â said Frodo bowing. <emphasis>âElen sila lumennâ omentielvo</emphasis>, a star shines on the hour of our meeting,â he added in the high-elven speech.</p>
<p>âBe careful, friends!â cried Gildor laughing. âSpeak no secrets! Here is a scholar in the Ancient Tongue. Bilbo was a good master. Hail, Elf-friend!â he said, bowing to Frodo. âCome now with your friends and join our company! You had best walk in the middle so that you may not stray. You may be weary before we halt.â</p>
<p>âWhy? Where are you going?â asked Frodo.</p>
<p>âFor tonight we go to the woods on the hills above Woodhall. It is some miles, but you shall have rest at the end of it, and it will shorten your journey tomorrow.â</p>
<p>They now marched on again in silence, and passed like shadows and faint lights: for Elves (even more than hobbits) could walk when they wished without sound of footfall. Pippin soon began to feel sleepy, and staggered once or twice; but each time a tall Elf at his side put out his arm and saved him from a fall. <p>The woods on either side became denser; the trees were now younger and thicker; and as the lane went lower, running down into a fold of the hills, there were many deep brakes of hazel on the rising slopes at either hand. At last the Elves turned aside from the path. A green ride lay almost unseen through the thickets on the right; and this they followed as it wound away back up the wooded slopes on to the top of a shoulder of the hills that stood out into the lower land of the river-valley. Suddenly they came out of the shadow of the trees, and before them lay a wide space of grass, grey under the night. On three sides the woods pressed upon it; but eastward the ground fell steeply and the tops of the dark trees, growing at the bottom of the slope, were below their feet. Beyond, the low lands lay dim and flat under the stars. Nearer at hand a few lights twinkled in the village of Woodhall.</p>
<p>The Elves sat on the grass and spoke together in soft voices; they seemed to take no further notice of the hobbits. Frodo and his companions wrapped themselves in cloaks and blankets, and drowsiness stole over them. The night grew on, and the lights in the valley went out. Pippin fell asleep, pillowed on a green hillock.</p>
<p>Away high in the East swung Remmirath, the Netted Stars, and slowly above the mists red Borgil rose, glowing like a jewel of fire. Then by some shift of airs all the mist was drawn away like a veil, and there leaned up, as he climbed over the rim of the world, the Swordsman of the Sky, Menelvagor with his shining belt. The Elves all burst into song. Suddenly under the trees a fire sprang up with a red light.</p>
<p>âCome!â the Elves called to the hobbits. âCome! Now is the time for speech and merriment!â</p>
<p>Pippin sat up and rubbed his eyes. He shivered. âThere is a fire in the hall, and food for hungry guests,â said an Elf standing before him.</p>
<p>At the south end of the greensward there was an opening. There the green floor ran on into the wood, and formed a wide space like a hall, roofed by the boughs of trees. Their great trunks ran like pillars down each side. In the middle there was a wood-fire blazing, and upon the tree-pillars torches with lights of gold and silver were burning steadily. The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks. Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drink; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes.</p>
<image l:href="#elves_woodyend.jpg"/><empty-line/><p>âThis is poor fare,â they said to the hobbits; âfor we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls. If ever you are our guests at home, we will treat you better.â</p>
<p>âIt seems to me good enough for a birthday-party,â said Frodo.</p>
<p>Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink, for his mind was filled with the light upon the elf-faces, and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that he felt in a waking dream. But he remembered that there was bread, surpassing the savour of a fair white loaf to one who is starving; and fruits sweet as wildberries and richer than the tended fruits of gardens; he drained a cup that was filled with a fragrant draught, cool as a clear fountain, golden as a summer afternoon.</p>
<p>Sam could never describe in words, nor picture clearly to himself, what he felt or thought that night, though it remained in his memory as one of the chief events of his life. The nearest he ever got was to say: âWell, sir, if I could grow apples like that, I would call myself a gardener. But it was the singing that went to my heart, if you know what I mean.â</p>
<p>Frodo sat, eating, drinking, and talking with delight; but his mind was chiefly on the words spoken. He knew a little of the elf-speech and listened eagerly. Now and again he spoke to those that served him and thanked them in their own language. They smiled at him and said laughing: âHere is a jewel among hobbits!â</p>
<p>After a while Pippin fell fast asleep, and was lifted up and borne away to a bower under the trees; there he was laid upon a soft bed and slept the rest of the night away. Sam refused to leave his master. When Pippin had gone, he came and sat curled up at Frodoâs feet, where at last he nodded and closed his eyes. Frodo remained long awake, talking with Gildor.</p>
<p>They spoke of many things, old and new, and Frodo questioned Gildor much about happenings in the wide world outside the Shire. The tidings were mostly sad and ominous: of gathering darkness, the wars of Men, and the flight of the Elves. At last Frodo asked the question that was nearest to his heart:</p>
<p>âTell me, Gildor, have you ever seen Bilbo since he left us?â</p>
<p>Gildor smiled. âYes,â he answered. âTwice. He said farewell to us on this very spot. But I saw him once again, far from here.â He would say no more about Bilbo, and Frodo fell silent.</p>
<p>âYou do not ask me or tell me much that concerns yourself, Frodo,â said Gildor. âBut I already know a little, and I can read more in your face and in the thought behind your questions. <p>âIt is,â said Frodo; âbut I thought my going was a secret known only to Gandalf and my faithful Sam.â He looked down at Sam, who was snoring gently.</p>
<p>âThe secret will not reach the Enemy from us,â said Gildor.</p>
<p>âThe Enemy?â said Frodo. âThen you know why I am leaving the Shire?â</p>
<p>âI do not know for what reason the Enemy is pursuing you,â answered Gildor; âbut I perceive that he is â strange indeed though that seems to me. And I warn you that peril is now both before you and behind you, and upon either side.â</p>
<p>âYou mean the Riders? I feared that they were servants of the Enemy. What <emphasis>are</emphasis> the Black Riders?â</p>
<p>âHas Gandalf told you nothing?â</p>
<p>âNothing about such creatures.â</p>
<p>âThen I think it is not for me to say more â lest terror should keep you from your journey. For it seems to me that you have set out only just in time, if indeed you are in time. You must now make haste, and neither stay nor turn back; for the Shire is no longer any protection to you.â</p>
<p>âI cannot imagine what information could be more terrifying than your hints and warnings,â exclaimed Frodo. âI knew that danger lay ahead, of course; but I did not expect to meet it in our own Shire. Canât a hobbit walk from the Water to the River in peace?â</p>
<p>âBut it is not your own Shire,â said Gildor. âOthers dwelt here before hobbits were; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more. The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.â</p>
<p>âI know â and yet it has always seemed so safe and familiar. What can I do now? My plan was to leave the Shire secretly, and make my way to Rivendell; but now my footsteps are dogged, before ever I get to Buckland.â</p>
<p>âI think you should still follow that plan,â said Gildor. âI do not think the Road will prove too hard for your courage. But if you desire clearer counsel, you should ask Gandalf. I do not know the reason for your flight, and therefore I do not know by what means your pursuers will assail you. These things Gandalf must know. I suppose that you will see him before you leave the Shire?â</p>
<p>âI hope so. But that is another thing that makes me anxious. I have been expecting Gandalf for many days. He was to have come to Hobbiton at the latest two nights ago; but he has never appeared. Now I am wondering what can have happened. Should I wait for him?â</p>
<p>Gildor was silent for a moment. âI do not like this news,â he said at last. âThat Gandalf should be late, does not bode well. But it is said: <emphasis>Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards, for they are subtle and quick to anger</emphasis>. The choice is yours: to go or wait.â</p>
<p>âAnd it is also said,â answered Frodo: âGo <emphasis>not to the Elves for counsel, for they will say both no and yes.â</emphasis></p>
<p>âIs it indeed?â laughed Gildor. âElves seldom give unguarded advice, for advice is a dangerous gift, even from the wise to the wise, and all courses may run ill. But what would you? Now you should be grateful, for I do not give this counsel gladly. The Elves have their own labours and their own sorrows, and they are little concerned with the ways of hobbits, or of any other creatures upon earth. <p>âI am deeply grateful,â said Frodo; âbut I wish you would tell me plainly what the Black Riders are. If I take your advice I may not see Gandalf for a long while, and I ought to know what is the danger that pursues me.â</p>
<p>âIs it not enough to know that they are servants of the Enemy?â answered Gildor. âFlee them! Speak no words to them! They are deadly. Ask no more of me! <p>âBut where shall I find courage?â asked Frodo. âThat is what I chiefly need.â</p>
<p>âCourage is found in unlikely places,â said Gildor. âBe of good hope! Sleep now! In the morning we shall have gone; but we will send our messages through the lands. <p>Frodo felt sleep coming upon him, even as Gildor finished speaking. âI will sleep now,â he said; and the Elf led him to a bower beside Pippin, and he threw himself upon a bed and fell at once into a dreamless slumber.</p>
</section><section><title><p>Chapter 4</p>
<p>A Short Cut to Mushrooms</p>
</title><p>In the morning Frodo woke refreshed. He was lying in a bower made by a living tree with branches laced and drooping to the ground; his bed was of fern and grass, deep and soft and strangely fragrant. The sun was shining through the fluttering leaves, which were still green upon the tree. He jumped up and went out.</p>
<p>Sam was sitting on the grass near the edge of the wood. Pippin was standing studying the sky and weather. There was no sign of the Elves.</p>
<p>âThey have left us fruit and drink, and bread,â said Pippin. âCome and have your breakfast. The bread tastes almost as good as it did last night. I did not want to leave you any, but Sam insisted.â</p>
<p>Frodo sat down beside Sam and began to eat. âWhat is the plan for today?â asked Pippin.</p>
<p>âTo walk to Bucklebury as quickly as possible,â answered Frodo, and gave his attention to the food.</p>
<p>âDo you think we shall see anything of those Riders?â asked Pippin cheerfully. Under the morning sun the prospect of seeing a whole troop of them did not seem very alarming to him.</p>
<p>âYes, probably,â said Frodo, not liking the reminder. âBut I hope to get across the river without their seeing us.â</p>
<p>âDid you find out anything about them from Gildor?â</p>
<p>âNot much â only hints and riddles,â said Frodo evasively.</p>
<p>âDid you ask about the sniffing?â</p>
<p>âWe didnât discuss it,â said Frodo with his mouth full.</p>
<p>âYou should have. I am sure it is very important.â</p>
<p>âIn that case I am sure Gildor would have refused to explain it,â said Frodo sharply. âAnd now leave me in peace for a bit! I donât want to answer a string of questions while I am eating. I want to think!â</p>
<p>âGood heavens!â said Pippin. âAt breakfast?â He walked away towards the edge of the green.</p>
<p>From Frodoâs mind the bright morning â treacherously bright, he thought â had not banished the fear of pursuit; and he pondered the words of Gildor. The merry voice of Pippin came to him. He was running on the green turf and singing.</p>
<p>âNo! I could not!â he said to himself. âIt is one thing to take my young friends walking over the Shire with me, until we are hungry and weary, and food and bed are sweet. To take them into exile, where hunger and weariness may have no cure, is quite another â even if they are willing to come. The inheritance is mine alone. I donât think I ought even to take Sam.â He looked at Sam Gamgee, and discovered that Sam was watching him.</p>
<p>âWell, Sam!â he said. âWhat about it? I am leaving the Shire as soon as ever I can â in fact I have made up my mind now not even to wait a day at Crickhollow, if it can be helped.â</p>
<p>âVery good, sir!â</p>
<p>âYou still mean to come with me?â</p>
<p>âI do.â</p>
<p>âIt is going to be very dangerous, Sam. âIt is already dangerous. Most likely neither of us will come back.â</p>
<p>âIf you donât come back, sir, then I shanât, thatâs certain,â said Sam. <emphasis>âDonât you leave him!</emphasis> they said to me. <emphasis>Leave him!</emphasis> I said. <emphasis>I never mean to. I am going with him, if he climbs to the Moon, and if any of those Black Riders try to stop him, theyâll have Sam Gamgee to reckon with</emphasis>, I said. They laughed.â</p>
<p>âWho are <emphasis>they</emphasis>, and what are you talking about?â</p>
<p>âThe Elves, sir. We had some talk last night; and they seemed to know you were going away, so I didnât see the use of denying it. Wonderful folk, Elves, sir! Wonderful!â</p>
<p>âThey are,â said Frodo. âDo you like them still, now you have had a closer view?â</p>
<p>âThey seem a bit above my likes and dislikes, so to speak,â answered Sam slowly. âIt donât seem to matter what I think about them. They are quite different from what I expected â so old and young, and so gay and sad, as it were.â</p>
<p>Frodo looked at Sam rather startled, half expecting to see some outward sign of the odd change that seemed to have come over him. It did not sound like the voice of the old Sam Gamgee that he thought he knew. But it looked like the old Sam Gamgee sitting there, except that his face was unusually thoughtful.</p>
<p>âDo you feel any need to leave the Shire now â now that your wish to see them has come true already?â he asked.</p>
<p>âYes, sir. I donât know how to say it, but after last night I feel different. I seem to see ahead, in a kind of way. <p>âI donât altogether. But I understand that Gandalf chose me a good companion. I am content. We will go together.â</p>
<p>Frodo finished his breakfast in silence. Then standing up he looked over the land ahead, and called to Pippin.</p>
<p>âAll ready to start?â he said as Pippin ran up. âWe must be getting off at once. We slept late; and there are a good many miles to go.â</p>
<p><emphasis>âYou</emphasis> slept late, you mean,â said Pippin. âI was up long before; and we are only waiting for you to finish eating and thinking.â</p>
<p>âI have finished both now. And I am going to make for Bucklebury Ferry as quickly as possible. I am not going out of the way, back to the road we left last night: I am going to cut straight across country from here.â</p>
<p>âThen you are going to fly,â said Pippin. âYou wonât cut straight on foot anywhere in this country.â</p>
<p>âWe can cut straighter than the road anyway,â answered Frodo. âThe Ferry is east from Woodhall; but the hard road curves away to the left â you can see a bend of it away north over there. <p><emphasis>âShort cuts make long delays,â</emphasis> argued Pippin. âThe country is rough round here, and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the Marish â I know the land in these parts. <p>âIt is less easy to find people in the woods and fields,â answered Frodo. âAnd if you are supposed to be on the road, there is some chance that you will be looked for on the road and not off it.â</p>
<p>âAll right!â said Pippin. âI will follow you into every bog and ditch. But it is hard! I had counted on passing the <emphasis>Golden Perch</emphasis> at Stock before sundown. The best beer in the Eastfarthing, or used to be: it is a long time since I tasted it.â</p>
<p>âThat settles it!â said Frodo. âShort cuts make delays, but inns make longer ones. At all costs we must keep you away from the <emphasis>Golden Perch.</emphasis> We want to get to Bucklebury before dark. What do you say, Sam?â</p>
<p>âI will go along with you, Mr. Frodo,â said Sam (in spite of private misgiving and a deep regret for the best beer in the Eastfarthing).</p>
<p>âThen if we are going to toil through bog and briar, letâs go now!â said Pippin.</p>
<p>It was already nearly as hot as it had been the day before; but clouds were beginning to come up from the West. It looked likely to turn to rain. The hobbits scrambled down a steep green bank and plunged into the thick trees below. Their course had been chosen to leave Woodhall to their left, and to cut slanting through the woods that clustered along the eastern side of the hills, until they reached the flats beyond. Then they could make straight for the Ferry over country that was open, except for a few ditches and fences. Frodo reckoned they had eighteen miles to go in a straight line.</p>
<p>He soon found that the thicket was closer and more tangled than it had appeared. There were no paths in the undergrowth, and they did not get on very fast. When they had struggled to the bottom of the bank, they found a stream running down from the hills behind in a deeply dug bed with steep slippery sides overhung with brambles. Most inconveniently it cut across the line they had chosen. They could not jump over it, nor indeed get across it at all without getting wet, scratched, and muddy. They halted, wondering what to do. âFirst check!â said Pippin, smiling grimly.</p>
<p>Sam Gamgee looked back. Through an opening in the trees he caught a glimpse of the top of the green bank from which they had climbed down.</p>
<p>âLook!â he said, clutching Frodo by the arm. They all looked, and on the edge high above them they saw against the sky a horse standing. Beside it stooped a black figure.</p>
<p>They at once gave up any idea of going back. Frodo led the way, and plunged quickly into the thick bushes beside the stream. âWhew!â he said to Pippin. âWe were both right! <p>They stood still, almost holding their breath as they listened; but there was no sound of pursuit. âI donât fancy he would try bringing his horse down that bank,â said Sam. âBut I guess he knows we came down it. We had better be going on.â</p>
<p>Going on was not altogether easy. They had packs to carry, and the bushes and brambles were reluctant to let them through. They were cut off from the wind by the ridge behind, and the air was still and stuffy. When they forced their way at last into more open ground, they were hot and tired and very scratched, and they were also no longer certain of the direction in which they were going. The banks of the stream sank, as it reached the levels and became broader and shallower, wandering off towards the Marish and the River.</p>
<p>âWhy, this is the Stock-brook!â said Pippin. âIf we are going to try and get back on to our course, we must cross at once and bear right.â</p>
<p>They waded the stream, and hurried over a wide open space, rush-grown and treeless, on the further side. Beyond that they came again to a belt of trees: tall oaks, for the most part, with here and there an elm tree or an ash. The ground was fairly level, and there was little undergrowth; but the trees were loo close for them to see far ahead. The leaves blew upwards in sudden gusts of wind, and spots of rain began to fall from the overcast sky. Then the wind died away and the rain came streaming down. They trudged along as fast as they could, over patches of grass, and through thick drifts of old leaves; and all about them the rain pattered and trickled. <p>After half an hour Pippin said: âI hope we have not turned too much towards the south, and are not walking longwise through this wood! It is not a very broad belt âI should have said no more than a mile at the widest â and we ought to have been through it by now.â</p>
<p>âIt is no good our starting to go in zig-zags,â said Frodo. âThat wonât mend matters. Let us keep on as we are going! I am not sure that I want to come out into the open yet.â</p>
<p>They went on for perhaps another couple of miles. Then the sun gleamed out of ragged clouds again and the rain lessened. It was now past mid-day, and they felt it was high time for lunch. They halted under an elm tree: its leaves though fast turning yellow were still thick, and the ground at its feel was fairly dry and sheltered. When they came to make their meal, they found that the Elves had filled their bottles with a clear drink, pale golden in colour: it had the scent of a honey made of many flowers, and was wonderfully refreshing. Very soon they were laughing, and snapping their fingers at rain, and at Black Riders. The last few miles, they felt, would soon be behind them.</p>
<p>Frodo propped his back against the tree-trunk, and closed his eyes. Sam and Pippin sat near, and they began to hum, and then to sing softly:</p>
<poem><stanza><v>Ho! Ho! Ho! to the bottle I go</v><v>To heal my heart and drown my woe.</v><v>Rain may fall and wind may blow,</v><v>And many miles be still to go,</v><v>But under a tall tree I will lie,</v><v>And let the clouds go sailing by.</v></stanza></poem><p><emphasis>Ho! Ho! Ho!</emphasis> they began again louder. They stopped short suddenly. Frodo sprang to his feet. A long-drawn wail came down the wind, like the cry of some evil and lonely creature. It rose and fell, and ended on a high piercing note. Even as they sat and stood, as if suddenly frozen, it was answered by another cry, fainter and further off, but no less chilling to the blood. There was then a silence, broken only by the sound of the wind in the leaves.</p>
<p>âAnd what do you think that was?â Pippin asked at last, trying to speak lightly, but quavering a little. âIf it was a bird, it was one that I never heard in the Shire before.â</p>
<p>âIt was not bird or beast,â said Frodo. âIt was a call, or a signal â there were words in that cry, though I could not catch them. But no hobbit has such a voice.â</p>
<p>No more was said about it. They were all thinking of the Riders, but no one spoke of them. They were now reluctant either to stay or go on; but sooner or later they had got to get across the open country to the Ferry, and it was best to go sooner and in daylight. In a few moments they had shouldered their packs again and were off.</p>
<p>Before long the wood came to a sudden end. Wide grass-lands stretched before them. They now saw that they had, in fact, turned too much to the south. Away over the flats they could glimpse the low hill of Bucklebury across the River, but it was now to their left. Creeping cautiously out from the edge of the trees, they set off across the open as quickly as they could.</p>
<p>At first they felt afraid, away from the shelter of the wood. Far back behind them stood the high place where they had breakfasted. The line of the River grew nearer; and the Black Riders began to seem like phantoms of the woods now left far behind.</p>
<p>They passed along the edge of a huge turnip-field, and came to a stout gate. Beyond it a rutted lane ran between low well-laid hedges towards a distant clump of trees. Pippin stopped.</p>
<p>âI know these fields and this gate!â he said. âThis is Bamfurlong, old Farmer Maggotâs land. Thatâs his farm away there in the trees.â</p>
<p>âOne trouble after another!â said Frodo, looking nearly as much alarmed as if Pippin had declared the lane was the slot leading to a dragonâs den. The others looked at him in surprise.</p>
<p>âWhatâs wrong with old Maggot?â asked Pippin. âHeâs a good friend to all the Brandybucks. Of course heâs a terror to trespassers, and keeps ferocious dogs â but after all, folk down here are near the border and have to be more on their guard.â</p>
<p>âI know,â said Frodo. âBut all the same,â he added with a shamefaced laugh, âI am terrified of him and his dogs. I have avoided his farm for years and years. <p>Pippin laughed. âWell, itâs time you made it up. Especially if you are coming back to live in Buckland. Old Maggot is really a stout fellow â if you leave his mushrooms alone. <p>They went along the lane, until they saw the thatched roofs of a large house and farm-buildings peeping out among the trees ahead. <p>Suddenly as they drew nearer a terrific baying and barking broke out, and a loud voice was heard shouting: âGrip! Fang! Wolf! Come on, lads!â</p>
<p>Frodo and Sam stopped dead, but Pippin walked on a few paces. The gate opened and three huge dogs came pelting out into the lane, and dashed towards the travellers, barking fiercely. <p>Through the gate there now appeared a broad thick-set hobbit with a round red face. âHallo! Hallo! And who may you be, and what may you be wanting?â he asked.</p>
<p>âGood afternoon, Mr. Maggot!â said Pippin.</p>

<p>âWhat fellow do you mean?â asked Pippin.</p>
<p>âThen you havenât seen him?â said the farmer. âHe went up the lane towards the causeway not a long while back. He was a funny customer and asking funny questions. <p>It seemed plain that the farmer would tell them more, if allowed to do it in his own time and fashion, so they all accepted the invitation. âWhat about the dogs?â asked Frodo anxiously.</p>
<p>The farmer laughed. âThey wonât harm you â not unless I tell âem to. Here, Grip! Fang! Heel!â he cried. âHeel, Wolf!â To the relief of Frodo and Sam, the dogs walked away and let them go free.</p>
<p>Pippin introduced the other two to the farmer. âMr. Frodo Baggins,â he said. âYou may not remember him, but he used to live at Brandy Hall.â At the name Baggins the farmer started, and gave Frodo a sharp glance. <p>âWell, if that isnât queerer than ever?â he exclaimed. âMr. Baggins is it? Come inside! We must have a talk.â</p>
<p>They went into the farmerâs kitchen, and sat by the wide fire-place. Mrs. Maggot brought out beer in a huge jug, and filled four large mugs. <p>After a few remarks about the weather and the agricultural prospects (which were no worse than usual), Farmer Maggot put down his mug and looked at them all in turn.</p>
<p>âNow, Mr. Peregrin,â he said, âwhere might you be coming from, and where might you be going to? Were you coming to visitâ me? For, if so, you had gone past my gate without my seeing you.â</p>
<p>âWell, no,â answered Pippin. âTo tell you the truth, since you have guessed it, we got into the lane from the other end: we had come over your fields. But that was quite by accident. We lost our way in the woods, back near Woodhall, trying to take a short cut to the Ferry.â</p>
<p>âIf you were in a hurry, the road would have served you better,â said the farmer. âBut I wasnât worrying about that. You have leave to walk over my land, if you have a mind, Mr. Peregrin. <p>They waited anxiously for him to go on. âWell,â the farmer continued, approaching his point with slow relish, âhe came riding on a big black horse in at the gate, which happened to be open, and right up to my door. <p>â âBe off!â I said. âThere are no Bagginses here. Youâre in the wrong part of the Shire. You had better go back west to Hobbiton â but you can go by road this time.â</p>
<p>â âBaggins has left,â he answered in a whisper. âHe is coming. He is not far away. I wish to find him. If he passes will you tell me? I will come back with gold.â</p>
<p>â âNo you wonât,â I said. âYouâll go back where you belong, double quick. I give you one minute before I call all my dogs.â</p>
<p>âHe gave a sort of hiss. It might have been laughing, and it might not. Then he spurred his great horse right at me, and I jumped out of the way only just in time. <p>Frodo sat for a moment looking at the fire, but his only thought was how on earth would they reach the Ferry. âI donât know what to think,â he said at last.</p>
<p>âThen Iâll tell you what to think,â said Maggot. âYou should never have gone mixing yourself up with Hobbiton folk, Mr. Frodo. <p>âWell, Mr. Frodo,â Maggot went on, âIâm glad that youâve had the sense to come back to Buckland. My advice is: stay there! And donât get mixed up with these outlandish folk. <p>Maggot looked at him thoughtfully. âWell, I see you have ideas of your own,â he said. âIt is as plain as my nose that no accident brought you and that rider here on the same afternoon; and maybe my news was no great news to you, after all. <p>âI was thinking so,â said Frodo. âBut we have got to try and get there; and it wonât be done by sitting and thinking. So I am afraid we must be going. <p>âYouâll be welcome when you come,â said Maggot. âBut now Iâve a notion. Itâs near sundown already, and we are going to have our supper; for we mostly go to bed soon after the Sun. If you and Mr. Peregrin and all could stay and have a bite with us, we would be pleased!â</p>
<p>âAnd so should we!â said Frodo. âBut we must be going at once, Iâm afraid. Even now it will be dark before we can reach the Ferry.â</p>
<p>âAh! but wait a minute! I was going to say: after a bit of supper, Iâll get out a small waggon, and Iâll drive you all to the Ferry. That will save you a good step, and it might also save you trouble of another sort.â</p>
<p>Frodo now accepted the invitation gratefully, to the relief of Pippin and Sam. The sun was already behind the western hills, and the light was failing. <p>When they had finished, the farmer and his sons went out with a lantern and got the waggon ready. It was dark in the yard, when the guests came out. They threw their packs on board and climbed in. <p>âYou be careful of yourself, Maggot!â she called. âDonât go arguing with any foreigners, and come straight back!â</p>
<p>âI will!â said he, and drove out of the gate. There was now no breath of wind stirring; the night was still and quiet, and a chill was in the air. They went without lights and took it slowly. <p>Maggot got down and took a good look either way, north and south, but nothing could be seen in the darkness, and there was not a sound in the still air. Thin strands of river-mist were hanging above the dikes, and crawling over the fields.</p>
<p>âItâs going to be thick,â said Maggot; âbut Iâll not light my lantern till I turn for home. Weâll hear anything on the road long before we meet it tonight.â</p>
<p>It was five miles or more from Maggotâs lane to the Ferry. <p>They reached the entrance to the Ferry lane at last. It was marked by two tall white posts that suddenly loomed up on their right. <p>Maggot jumped down and stood holding the poniesâ heads, and peering forward into the gloom. <emphasis>Clip-clop, clip-clop</emphasis> came the approaching rider. The fall of the hoofs sounded loud in the still, foggy air.</p>
<p>âYouâd better be hidden, Mr. Frodo,â said Sam anxiously. âYou get down in the waggon and cover up with blankets, and weâll send this rider to the rightabouts!â He climbed out and went to the farmerâs side. Black Riders would have to ride over him to get near the waggon.</p>
<p><emphasis>Clop-clop, clop-clop</emphasis>. The rider was nearly on them.</p>
<p>âHallo there!â called Farmer Maggot. The advancing hoofs stopped short. <p>âI want Mr. Baggins. Have you seen him?â said a muffled voice â but the voice was the voice of Merry Brandybuck. A dark lantern was uncovered, and its light fell on the astonished face of the farmer.</p>
<p>âMr. Merry!â he cried.</p>
<p>âYes, of course! Who did you think it was?â said Merry coming forward. As he came out of the mist and their fears subsided, he seemed suddenly to diminish to ordinary hobbit-size. He was riding a pony, and a scarf was swathed round his neck and over his chin to keep out the fog.</p>
<p>Frodo sprang out of the waggon to greet him. âSo there you are at last!â said Merry. âI was beginning to wonder if you would turn up at all today, and I was just going back to supper. <p>âNo, I caught âem trespassing,â said the farmer, âand nearly set my dogs on âem; but theyâll tell you all the story, Iâve no doubt. <p>He backed the waggon into the lane and turned it. âWell, good night to you all,â he said. âItâs been a queer day, and no mistake. <p>They watched the pale rings of light round his lanterns as they dwindled into the foggy night. Suddenly Frodo laughed: from the covered basket he held, the scent of mushrooms was rising.</p>
</section><section><title><p>Chapter 5</p>
<p>A Conspiracy Unmasked</p>
</title><p>âNow we had better get home ourselves,â said Merry. Thereâs something funny about all this, I see; but it must wait till we get in.â</p>
<p>They turned down the Ferry lane, which was straight and well-kept and edged with large white-washed stones. In a hundred yards or so it brought them to the river-bank, where there was a broad wooden landing-stage. A large flat ferry-boat was moored beside it. The white bollards near the waterâs edge glimmered in the light of two lamps on high posts. Behind them the mists in the flat fields were now above the hedges; but the water before them was dark, with only a few curling wisps like steam among the reeds by the bank. There seemed to be less fog on the further side.</p>
<p>Merry led the pony over a gangway on to the ferry, and the others followed. Merry then pushed slowly off with a long pole. The Brandywine flowed slow and broad before them. On the other side the bank was steep, and up it a winding path climbed from the further landing. Lamps were twinkling there. Behind loomed up the Buck Hill; and out of it, through stray shrouds of mist, shone many round windows, yellow and red. They were the windows of Brandy Hall, the ancient home of the Brandybucks.</p>
<p>Long ago Gorhendad Oldbuck, head of the Oldbuck family, one of the oldest in the Marish or indeed in the Shire, had crossed the river, which was the original boundary of the land eastwards. He built (and excavated) Brandy Hall, changed his name to Brandybuck, and settled down to become master of what was virtually a small independent country. His family grew and grew, and after his days continued to grow, until Brandy Hall occupied the whole of the low hill, and had three large front-doors, many side-doors, and about a hundred windows. The Brandybucks and their numerous dependants then began to burrow, and later to build, all round about. That was the origin of Buckland, a thickly inhabited strip between the river and the Old Forest, a sort of colony from the Shire. Its chief village was Bucklebury, clustering in the banks and slopes behind Brandy Hall.</p>
<p>The people in the Marish were friendly with the Bucklanders, and the authority of the Master of the Hall (as the head of the Brandybuck family was called) was still acknowledged by the farmers between Stock and Rushey. But most of the folk of the old Shire regarded the Bucklanders as peculiar, half foreigners as it were. Though, as a matter of fact, they were not very different from the other hobbits of the Four Farthings. Except in one point: they were fond of boats, and some of them could swim.</p>
<p>Their land was originally unprotected from the East; but on that side they had built a hedge: the High Hay. It had been planted many generations ago, and was now thick and tall, for it was constantly tended. It ran all the way from Brandywine Bridge, in a big loop curving away from the river, to Haysend (where the Withywindle flowed out of the Forest into the Brandywine): well over twenty miles from end to end. But, of course, it was not a complete protection. The Forest drew close to the hedge in many places. The Bucklanders kept their doors locked after dark, and that also was not usual in the Shire.</p>
<p>The ferry-boat moved slowly across the water. The Buckland shore drew nearer. Sam was the only member of the party who had not been over the river before. He had a strange feeling as the slow gurgling stream slipped by: his old life lay behind in the mists, dark adventure lay in front. He scratched his head, and for a moment had a passing wish that Mr. Frodo could have gone on living quietly at Bag End.</p>

</section><section><title><p>Chapter 6</p>
<p>The Old Forest</p>
</title><p>Frodo woke suddenly. It was still dark in the room. Merry was standing there with a candle in one hand, and banging on the door with the other. âAll right! What is it?â said Frodo, still shaken and bewildered.</p>

<p>Soon after six oâclock the five hobbits were ready to start. Fatty Bolger was still yawning. They stole quietly out of the house.
